(Code 1957, § 16-19(1)(a), (b), (e)-(r), (t)-(y); Code 1994, § 46-69; Ord. No. 96-7779, § 1, 8-21-1996; Ord. No. 98-8434, § 1, 12-16-1998; Ord. No. 07-11560, § 2, 2-21-2007; Ord. No. 08-12306, § 1, 12-17-2008) 
Sec. 28-35. - Animals; glass containers. 
(a)  Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection: 
    Animal means any living dumb creature. 
    Glass container means any glass receptacle, bottle or dish. Such objects as binoculars, eyeglasses, jewelry, face masks or any object other than a container are not included. 
    Owner means any person with the right or duty to control or any person owning, possessing, harboring or keeping an animal. 
(b)  Glass containers prohibited. No person shall take into any public park of the city any glass container or be in possession of any glass container in any public park of the city. 
(c)  Animals. It shall be lawful for the owner of an animal to allow such animal to enter or be within any public park of the city, unless designated otherwise, providing that the animal must be on a leashed restraint and under owner control at all times, that the owner must remove and properly dispose of all animal waste and that the owner is responsible for all actions of the animal. Animals are not allowed on any city beach or in any playground. Any person violating this section shall be guilty of an infraction, which shall be punishable by a fine of not less than $50.00 per violation with each day or partial day of violation counting as a separate offense. 
(Code 1957, §§ 16-19(1)(s), 16-30; Code 1994, § 46-70; Ord. No. 06-11360, § 1, 9-10-2006) 
Sec. 28-36. - Fires prohibited. 
    No person shall build or attempt to build a fire in any park within the city except by approval of city council. 
(Code 1957, § 16-31; Code 1994, § 46-71; Ord. No. 07-11560, § 3, 2-21-2007; Ord. No. 09-12391, § 1, 3-18-2009) 
Sec. 28-37. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 07-11560, § 4, adopted February, 21, 2007, repealed § 28-37, which pertained to tennis, racquetball and shuffleboard courts schedule of fees. See also the Code Comparative Table. 
Secs. 28-38-28-60. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - CONSERVATION AND PRESERVATION OF LAND[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Resource protection standards, ch. 52. 

Sec. 28-61. - Objectives. 
    The objectives of the Naples Land Conservation Program are the acquisition, conservation, preservation, restoration, and maintenance of: 
(1)  Vital and significant threatened natural lands, forest, upland and wetland communities; 
(2)  Environmentally sensitive lands; 
(3)  Lands that have been altered but are capable of being restored; 
(4)  Improved or unimproved lands that may be useful; 
(5)  Interests in lands such as conservation easements, scenic easements and any other interests, located within and adjacent to the city, for the benefit of present and future generations. 
(Code 1994, § 46-77; Ord. No. 05-10818, § 1, 5-4-2005) 
Sec. 28-62. - Purpose and intent of article. 
    The purposes and intent of this article are as follows: 
(1)  To acquire, protect and manage environmentally sensitive lands that contain natural upland or wetland communities, native plant communities, rare and endangered flora and fauna, endemic species, endangered species habitat, a diversity of species, significant water resources, or outstanding aesthetic or other natural features, maximizing protection of unique or endangered habitats; 
(2)  To acquire, protect and manage environmentally sensitive lands that offer the best human social value, including equitable geographic distribution, natural resource based recreation, and protection of water resources, local ecological awareness, and enhancement of the aesthetic setting of the city; 
(3)  To acquire, protect and manage environmentally sensitive lands that serve to recharge the county's aquifers and protect its wetlands and surface water resources to ensure the delivery of clean and plentiful water supplies and provide flood control; 
(4)  To acquire, protect and manage environmentally sensitive lands containing the most biological value, including biodiversity, listed species habitat, connectivity, restoration potential, and ecological quality; 
(5)  To protect present conservation or preservation lands by acquiring, protecting and managing adjacent properties which, if not acquired, would threaten the environmental integrity of the existing resource, or which, if acquired, would enhance and buffer the environmental integrity of the resource, and add to resource connectivity; 
(6)  To restore the natural functions, as necessary, to any impacted and vulnerable habitats which would then contribute significantly to fulfilling this program's goals; 
(7)  To help implement the objectives and policies of the comprehensive plan which have been promulgated to preserve and protect environmental protection areas designated in the plan and other natural forest resources, wetlands, endangered species habitat, and vulnerable rare habitats; 
(8)  To identify the city's best and most endangered environmental lands for acquisition, protection and management by evaluating the biological and hydrological characteristics and viability of the resource, the vulnerability of the resource to degradation or destruction, and the feasibility of managing the resource to maintain its natural attributes; 
(9)  To manage acquired environmentally sensitive lands with the primary objectives of maintaining and preserving their natural resource values, and providing appropriate natural resource based recreational and educational opportunities, by employing management techniques that are most appropriate for each native community so that our natural heritage may be preserved and appreciated by and for present and future generations; 
(10)  To preserve lands that may not qualify as environmentally sensitive, but are otherwise worthy of restoration and preservation for the health, safety and welfare of the citizenry; 
(11)  To acquire and manage interests in land such as conservation easements, scenic easements and any other interests that may assist in conservation or preservation of lands; 
(12)  To protect natural resources which lie within the boundaries of other conservation land acquisition programs, where funds would leverage significant other matching sources of funding for other agency acquisition projects that would not be available without such a local match, or which would result in considerably higher funding rank in another program and to enter into interlocal or other agreements for conservation and preservation; 
(13)  To cooperate actively with other acquisition, conservation, and resource management programs, including, but not limited to, such programs as program, the State of Florida Conservation and Recreation Lands program, the Land Acquisition Trust Fund, Florida Forever, and Save Our Rivers Program, where the purposes of such programs are consistent with the purposes of this program. 
(14)  To provide for acquisition, maintenance and preservation of a system of passive parks. 
(Code 1994, § 46-78; Ord. No. 05-10818, § 1, 5-4-2005) 
Sec. 28-63. - Definitions. 
    The following words and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section: 
    Acquisition project means 1 or more parcels of land that have been approved by the council for conservation or preservation. 
    Acquisition proposal means an application for nomination or recommendation of 1 or more parcels of land, or interests in land, for conservation or preservation. 
    Buffer land means land which is adjacent to publicly owned environmental land, or privately held land permanently dedicated to conservation, or that land which is an in-holding within publicly owned environmental land, and which, if not acquired, would threaten the environmental integrity of the existing resource, or if acquired, would enhance the environmental integrity and connectivity of the resource. 
    Environmentally sensitive land means land which contains natural upland or wetland communities, native plant communities, rare and endangered flora and fauna, endemic species, endangered species habitat, a diversity of species, significant water resources, or outstanding aesthetic or other natural features. 
    Management means the preservation, enhancement, restoration, conservation, monitoring, or maintenance of the natural resource values of lands which have been acquired or approved for management under this program, including provision of appropriate public access. 
    Natural resource based recreation means all forms of uses which are consistent with the goals of this program, and are compatible with the specific parcel. Such uses shall include but not be limited to hiking, nature photography, bird-watching, kayaking, canoeing, swimming, hunting and fishing. 
    Nonprofit organization means an organization as defined in section 501 of the United States Internal Revenue Code, which includes among its primary goals the conservation of natural resources and the protection of the environment. 
    Target protection areas means larger areas of environmentally sensitive land or other land within which are located specific sites which generally satisfy the initial screening criteria and meet the goals of this program. 
(Code 1994, § 46-79; Ord. No. 05-10818, § 1, 5-4-2005) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 28-64. - Land conservation trust fund. 
    The city council hereby establishes the Naples Land Conservation Trust Fund (the "fund") for use in acquiring and managing conservation and preservation lands in the city and for any purposes set forth in the Naples Land Conservation Program (the "program"). The fund shall receive and disburse monies in accordance with the provisions in this section. 
(1)  The fund may receive and apply monies from the following sources: 
a.  All monies accepted by the city in the form of federal, state, or other governmental grants, reimbursements, allocations, or appropriations, foundation or private grants, donations for acquisition of environmentally sensitive lands and payments provided for mitigation activity associated with such acquisition activity. 
b.  All monies from additional allocations as may be made by the city council from time to time for the purposes set forth in the program. 
c.  All interest or other income generated from the sources identified herein except where monies received have been otherwise designated or restricted. 
d.  Funds from borrowing from any lawful source including without limitation loans or bonds; interlocal or other public or private agreements. 
e.  To invest any funds held in reserves or sinking funds, or any funds not required for immediate disbursement, in such investments as may be authorized for trust funds under F.S. § 215.47 as amended. 
(2)  The fund shall be maintained in a separate and segregated trust fund of the city to be used solely for the authorized purposes set forth in the program. 
(3)  Disbursements from the fund shall be made for the following authorized purposes: 
a.  Acquisition of properties which have been approved for purchase by resolution of the council. 
b.  Costs associated with each acquisition including, but not limited to, appraisals, surveys, title search work, real property taxes, documentary stamps and surtax fees, and other transaction costs. 
c.  Costs of administering the program, including any loans from the general fund for funding start-up costs until such time as the fund is closed. Administration of the program may be conducted by city staff or by contract with a private entity. 
d.  To undertake and carry out studies and analyses of program needs and ways of meeting those needs. 
e.  To acquire and dispose of real and personal property or any interest therein when such acquisition is necessary or appropriate to protect the natural environment, provide public access or public recreational facilities, preserve wildlife habitat areas or provide access to management of acquired lands; to acquire interests in land by means of land exchanges; and to enter into alternatives to the acquisition of fee interests in land, including the acquisition of easements, life estates, leases, and leaseback arrangements, and to make any other disbursements consistent with the purposes of the program. 
f.  To fund acquisitions consistent with the comprehensive plan or land development code. 
g.  To provide funding in cooperation with other local, regional, state, or federal public land acquisition programs or public-private ventures. The city may enter into agreements to acquire lands jointly or for eventual resale to other public land acquisition programs in Collier County. 
h.  To borrow money through loans or the issuance of bonds for the purposes provided herein, to provide for and secure the payment thereof, and to provide for the rights of the holders thereof. 
i.  To insure and procure insurance against any loss in connection with any of the trust's operations, including without limitation: 
1.  The repayment of any loans to mortgage lenders or mortgage loans; 
2.  Any project; 
3.  Any bonds of the city; 
Insurance may be procured in such amounts and from such insurers, including the federal government, as may be deemed necessary or desirable by the city. 
j.  To engage the services of private consultants on a contract basis for rendering professional and technical assistance and advice. 
k.  To identify parcels of land that would be appropriate acquisitions. 
l.  To do any and all things necessary or convenient to carry out the purposes of and exercise the powers given and granted herein to the full extent of the law. 
(Code 1994, § 46-80; Ord. No. 05-10818, § 1, 5-4-2005) 
Sec. 28-65. - Administration. 
    The program shall be managed by the city manager through the designated administrative staff. The council retains the authority to approve application proposals, borrowings, disbursements and disposition of property. The council may approve interlocal or other agreements for the management of any portion or all of the program. 
(Code 1994, § 46-81; Ord. No. 05-10818, § 1, 5-4-2005) 
Sec. 28-66. - Properties eligible for acquisition and management. 
(a)  Properties eligible to be considered for acquisition and management under the program shall be only those lands, or interests in them, described in this article that are available from willing and voluntary participants. 
(b)  Acquisition of property shall not be constrained based on the immediate availability of management money. 
(c)  Any property not on the acquisition list which is offered for conveyance or donation to the city and is proposed for management under this program shall be evaluated as provided for in this article and may only be accepted and approved for management by the council. 
(Code 1994, § 46-82; Ord. No. 05-10818, § 1, 5-4-2005) 
Sec. 28-67. - Criteria for evaluation of lands for acquisition and management. 
(a)  The evaluation of each acquisition proposal shall be based on satisfying at least 1 or more of the initial screening criteria below. Qualified sites shall then be further prioritized by secondary evaluative criteria listed below under subsection (b) of this section. The initial screening criteria are: 
(1)  Land with the most rare, unique and endangered habitats found in the city. 
(2)  Land offering the best human social values, including equitable geographic distribution, appropriate access for natural resource based recreation, and enhancement of the aesthetic setting of the city. 
(3)  Land which protects the most water resource values, including aquifer recharge, water quality, wetland dependant species habitat, and flood control. 
(4)  Land containing the most biological value, including biodiversity, listed species habitat, connectivity, restoration potential, and ecological quality. 
(5)  Land which enhances or protects the environment total value of current conservation lands through function as a buffer, ecological link, or habitat corridor. 
(6)  Any qualified land which meets at least 1 or more of the above criteria, and has matching funds available, is a significant bargain sale, or for which program funds availability would leverage a significantly higher funding rank in another acquisition program. 
(b)  Those proposed acquisition proposals which are initially qualified under the screening criteria shall be evaluated and ranked by the administrative staff using secondary ranking criteria based on site visit information which confirms or refutes the initial screening criteria evaluation, and based on comparative size (to prefer larger of similar parcels), vulnerability to destruction (to prefer most threatened of qualified parcels), overall resource ecological quality (to prefer highest quality of similar parcels) and the estimated feasibility and costs of management (to prefer most manageable parcels). 
(c)  The council shall approve and make a part hereof the attached initial list of target protection areas within which are located specific sites which generally satisfy the initial screening criteria and meet the goals of the program. Inclusion on this list is not a guarantee of any specific purchase. All specific proposals will be evaluated and ranked by the administrative staff for a recommendation of approval to the council. In accordance with the goals, policies and procedures of this article, the following list is the first list of target protection areas adopted for consideration. 
(1)  All designated conservation or preservation lands on the future land use map of the city's comprehensive plan with predominantly native vegetative cover. 
(2)  All natural resource protection areas, as shown on the future land use map. 
(3)  All undeveloped lands with predominantly native vegetative cover. 
(d)  The city manager shall prepare and periodically update, for presentation to the council, a Naples Conservation Lands Program manual or brochure, developed by administrative staff, which, upon approval by the council, shall be used as a guide for implementing the provisions of this article, and shall also include the initial and secondary criteria listed hereinabove for evaluating acquisition proposals. 
(Code 1994, § 46-83; Ord. No. 05-10818, § 1, 5-4-2005) 
Sec. 28-68. - Acquisition list. 
    The overall Naples Conservation Program Acquisition List shall consist of 2 specific lists: the target protection areas list and the active acquisition list. The council shall approve both in accordance with the procedures set forth below: 
(1)  The target protection areas list shall consist of lands representing the highest natural resource values (such as natural resource protection areas), but generally not specific parcels, and is initially approved by the council and updated periodically by the council. It is established and updated in accordance with program goals, procedures and criteria. 
(2)  The active acquisition list shall consist of criteria-qualified sites that have been selected from target protection areas, as well as qualified acquisition proposals submitted by the public, all of which have received positive responses from the property owners. The active acquisition list shall be updated periodically according to program procedures and criteria. Site acquisition proposals that receive the highest evaluations pursuant to the program criteria and for which acquisition is feasible will be placed on this list, pending approval by the council. 
(3)  Once approved by the council, the city shall actively pursue acquisition of projects on the active acquisition list. All sites shall be pursued on a voluntary basis only, without the use of the city's eminent domain powers. 
(4)  Projects will only be removed from the active acquisition list by successful purchase of the site, approval of the next succeeding list, withdrawal of positive interest by the property owner, or by resolution of the council. Projects removed may still be considered at a later time. 
(Code 1994, § 46-84; Ord. No. 05-10818, § 1, 5-4-2005) 
Sec. 28-69. - Nomination of acquisition proposals and candidate sites. 
(a)  Specific site consideration will be given to all individual properties which lie within the target protection areas list and which have generated a positive interest response to a letter of acquisition inquiry sent by the city's designated contact. 
(b)  Public and landowner applications nominating properties for acquisition may be submitted at any time, during or after the first annual public solicitation meeting (described below), by any person or organization, including the city, Collier County, or other regional, state or federal agencies. 
(c)  All nominations shall be made by filing an application with the city manager, which will then be forwarded to designated administrative staff for review. 
(d)  There will be an annual public meeting for the purpose of updating the council and the public and for soliciting proposals and applications. The first such meeting will take place by the end of the first year of implementation of the program. The first annual meeting will be conducted upon adoption of the ordinance from which this section is derived. Future meetings will be held annually in conjunction with the city's budget cycle. 
(e)  If the applicant has an ownership interest in any real property covered by an application for proposed acquisition, such interest shall be disclosed in the same manner as required of zoning applicants, as required by the land development code and state law. This shall not apply to governmental applicants. 
(f)  If the applicant does not have an ownership interest in the real property covered by an application or if the applicant is a governmental agency, the name and address of the owner as listed in the property appraiser's records shall be provided with the application. 
(Code 1994, § 46-85; Ord. No. 05-10818, § 1, 5-4-2005) 
Sec. 28-70. - Procedure for selection of acquisition proposals for placement on the active acquisition list and subsequent purchase procedures. 
(a)  Administrative staff will send letters of inquiry to all property owners within the target protection areas. Positive responses will be forwarded to designated staff for preliminary review, using the initial screening criteria. 
(b)  After the first annual public solicitation of nominations, property owner and publicly nominated projects will be forwarded first to city staff for the mailing of inquiry letters. Designated staff using the initial screening criteria will review all positive responses. 
(c)  Nominated properties that do not fulfill the purposes of the program or do not satisfy the initial criteria will not be evaluated further. The city manager will notify the nominating person of the decision. If the nominating person disagrees with the decision of the city manager, that person may appeal the decision to the council by filing an appeal with the city manager within 30 days after the date of mailing of the decision. The council will conduct a hearing on the appeal and render a decision, which shall constitute final agency action. 
(d)  Proposals which satisfy the initial screening are then considered by the administrative staff for secondary criteria review and ranking. Staff shall consider with each proposal: boundary and location maps for each site, descriptions of the biological and hydrological characteristics, including initial criteria satisfied, a summary of its potential for appropriate use, development potential of the site and adjacent land, an assessment of the management needs and costs, the assessed value, and any potentially available matching funds. This acquisition proposal information shall be the initial criteria screening report. 
(e)  Upon completion of the initial criteria screening report, the council shall hold a public hearing to consider the recommendations regarding each site, the applicants' and landowners' comments, and comments from the public. A courtesy notice shall be provided to the owners of properties which are the subject of the hearing, although failure to notify said owners shall not invalidate these proceedings. The council shall evaluate all qualified proposals using the secondary ranking criteria, the initial criteria screening report, and public comments, then propose top-ranked proposals for the active acquisition list at this hearing. Subsequent meetings may be called to complete this task. 
(f)  The council shall vote on whether to approve all or part of the proposed active acquisition list and any additions that may be added to it. Additions may be added but any additional properties must be subjected to the entire evaluation process. 
(g)  After approval of the list, the administrative staff will prepare a project design report for each project, including appraisals, title research, history and purpose of project, and program qualifications. 
(h)  The council, after approval of the active acquisition list and the administrative staff's recommendations for negotiations, will instruct staff to negotiate for purchase for each listed project, with optional use of a 3rd party nonprofit organization negotiator, as authorized by the council. 
(i)  Upon successful completion of negotiations, staff will present to the council the proposed contract terms for review and approval. Staff will also forward the recommendations for contracts recommended for approval and for contracts that should not proceed as negotiated. 
(Code 1994, § 46-86; Ord. No. 05-10818, § 1, 5-4-2005) 
Sec. 28-71. - Management plans and use of environmentally sensitive lands. 
(a)  No later than 60 days from the date of acquisition, an interim management plan for any property acquired shall be submitted by staff to the council for approval and shall be implemented by the city manager pursuant to the council's direction. An interim management plan shall not be implemented for more than 2 years after acquisition of the property. Prior to the expiration of 2 years, either a new management plan shall be implemented or, by affirmative action of the council, the interim plan shall continue. 
(b)  A final management plan, with required review and updating every 10 years, shall be prepared, for each property, and shall: 
(1)  Identify such management activities as are necessary to preserve, enhance, restore, conserve, maintain, or monitor the resource, as appropriate; and 
(2)  Identify such uses as are consistent with the preservation, enhancement, restoration, conservation, and maintenance of the resource; and 
(3)  Estimate the annual costs of managing the project. 
(c)  If the final management plan is submitted within 60 days prior to closing, an interim management plan shall not be required. 
(d)  Annually, the 10-year management plans prepared during the preceding year shall be submitted to the council for review and update. Each 10-year management plan shall be updated at least every 5 years from the last date of council approval, and may be amended as often as required. 
(e)  All management plans shall be consistent with the purposes set forth herein. All properties acquired or managed through program shall be managed in accordance with the approved management plan for that property. 
(f)  No use, infrastructure, or improvement shall be permitted on any property acquired or managed under the program that is inconsistent with the purposes of the program or that is not provided by an approved management plan for the property. 
(g)  The city will seek cooperative management arrangements with other agencies and entities. 
(h)  Purchasing land using program funds permanently extinguishes all development rights except those strictly compatible with the purposes and goals of the program. 
(i)  Public access is an important element of management and this program. Examples of permitted uses, subject to compatibility with specific parcels, include: hiking, nature photography, bird-watching, kayaking, canoeing, swimming, hunting and fishing. The program will also make the acquired sites available, with minimal risk to the environmental integrity of the site, to educate Collier County's school-age population and the general public about the uniqueness and importance of the city's subtropical ecosystems and natural communities. 
(j)  Passive use parks will be an element of this program. 
(Code 1994, § 46-87; Ord. No. 05-10818, § 1, 5-4-2005) 
Chapter 29 - PERSONNEL 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 29-1-29-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - FEDERAL OLD-AGE AND SURVIVORS INSURANCE[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Federal old age and survivor's benefits, F.S. Ch. 650. 

Sec. 29-31. - Extended to city employees. 
    It is declared to be the policy and purpose of the city to extend, effective as of January 1, 1951, to the employees and officials thereof not excluded by law and where employed in connection with a governmental or proprietary function the benefits of the system of old-age and survivors insurance as authorized by the federal social security act and amendments thereto, including PL 734 of 81st Congress, and by Laws of Fla. ch. 26841 (1951) and to cover by such plan all services which constitute employment as defined in Laws of Fla. ch. 26841 (1951), § 2 performed in the employ of the city by employees thereof. In pursuance of this policy and for that purpose, the city shall take such action as may be required by applicable state or federal laws or regulations. 
(Code 1957, § 18-5; Code 1994, § 50-151) 
Sec. 29-32. - Authority to make necessary agreements. 
    The mayor or other chief executive officer of the city is authorized and directed to execute all necessary agreements and amendments to the system of old-age and survivors insurance with the state agency for the purpose of extending the benefits provided by such system to the employees and officials of this city as provided in section 29-31, which agreement shall provide for such methods of administration of the plan by the city as are found by the state agency to be necessary for the proper and efficient administration thereof and shall be effective with respect to services in employment covered by such agreement performed after January 1, 1951. 
(Code 1957, § 18-6; Code 1994, § 50-152) 
Sec. 29-33. - Withholdings. 
    Withholdings from salaries, wages or other compensation of employees and officials for the purpose provided in section 29-31 are authorized to be made and shall be made in the amounts and at such times as may be required by applicable state or federal laws or regulations and shall be paid over to the state agency designated by such laws or regulations to receive such amounts. 
(Code 1957, § 18-7; Code 1994, § 50-153) 
Sec. 29-34. - Use of city funds. 
    There shall be appropriated from available funds, derived from general fund and waterworks funds, such amounts, at such times, as may be required to pay promptly the contributions for old-age and survivors insurance required of the city as employer by applicable state or federal laws or regulations, which shall be paid over to the lawfully designated state agency at the times and in the manner provided by law and regulation. 
(Code 1957, § 18-8; Code 1994, § 50-154) 
Sec. 29-35. - Records of city. 
    The city shall keep such records and make such reports as may be required by applicable state or federal laws or regulations for federal old-age and survivors insurance and shall adhere to the rules and regulations of the state agency for the enforcement of such laws and regulations. 
(Code 1957, § 18-9; Code 1994, § 50-155) 
Sec. 29-36. - Employees otherwise covered exempt. 
    There is excluded from this article any authority to make any agreement with respect to any position or any employee or official covered or authorized to be covered by any other ordinance or law creating any retirement system for any employee or official of the city on the effective date of the ordinance from which this section derives. 
(Code 1957, § 18-10; Code 1994, § 50-156) 
Sec. 29-37. - Social security act adopted. 
    The city adopts the terms, conditions, requirements, reservations, benefits, privileges and other conditions thereunto appertaining of title II of the social security act as amended by PL 734, 81st Congress, for and on behalf of all the officers and employees thereof and of its departments and agencies, save and except any of such officers and employees covered or authorized to be covered by any retirement system provided by law on the effective date of the ordinance from which this section derives and further excepting any official or employee who occupies any position, office or employment not authorized to be covered by applicable state or federal laws or regulations. 
(Code 1957, § 18-11; Code 1994, § 50-157) 
Sec. 29-38. - Custodians, withholding and reporting agents designated. 
    The city clerk and mayor are designated the custodians of all sums withheld from the compensation of officers and employees and of the appropriated funds for the contribution of the city under this article, and the city clerk is made the withholding and reporting agent and charged with the duty of maintaining personnel records for the purposes of this article. 
(Code 1957, § 18-12; Code 1994, § 50-158) 
Secs. 29-39-29-65. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - RETIREMENT SYSTEM[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Actuarial soundness of local government pensions, F.S. § 112.60 et seq. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 29-66. - Established; effective date; merger of systems. 
(a)  The city retirement system is established for the purpose of providing pension and other benefits for certain employees of the city and their eligible beneficiaries. 
(b)  The effective date of the city retirement system shall be January 1, 1973. 
(c)  The retirement program established effective December 1, 1953 and as evidenced by group annuity contract GL-163 issued by The Life Insurance Company of Virginia is merged into and replaced by the city retirement system established by this article. 
(d)  Effective September 30, 2011, and notwithstanding any other provision of this Article III, the accrued benefits of all members of the retirement system who are employed by the city and not participating in the DROP on that date shall be frozen. The value of each member's frozen accrued benefit shall be calculated in accordance with the provisions of the retirement system in effect on September 29, 2011, and such frozen accrued benefit shall be payable to the member upon attaining eligibility for receipt of normal retirement benefits under the provisions of the system in effect on that date, and separation from city employment. For credited service on and after October 1, 2011, all members of the retirement system shall accrue benefits in accordance with the provisions of this Article III, as amended effective September 30, 2011. Members of the retirement system who are employed by the city and not participating in the DROP on September 30, 2011 shall, upon retirement, be eligible to receive a retirement benefit consisting of two parts: (1) the frozen accrued benefit based on credited service prior to October 1, 2011, and the provisions of the retirement system in effect on September 29, 2011; and (2) the accrued benefit based on credited service on and after October 1, 2011 and the provisions of this Article III, as amended effective September 30, 2011; payable at age 60 with five or more years of credited service, or the date on which a member's age to last completed month plus credited service totals 85 years or more and the member has five or more years of credited service, whichever occurs first. Members of the retirement system who are hired on or after October 1, 2011 shall accrue benefits in accordance with the provisions of this Article III, as amended effective September 30, 2011, payable at age 65 with eight or more years of credited service, or upon attainment of 33 years of credited service, whichever occurs first. 
(e)  Notwithstanding any other provision of this article III, the benefit changes contained in Ordinance No. 11-12951 shall not apply to any member who was employed by the city on September 30, 2011, and who as of that date had attained age 60 with five or more years of credited service, or the date on which a member's age to last completed month plus credited service totals 85 years or more and the member had five or more years of credited service. 
(Code 1957, § 18-21; Code 1994, § 50-186; Ord. No. 11-12951, § 1, 9-21-2011; Ord. No. 12-13142, § 1, 6-13-2012 ) 
Sec. 29-67. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Accumulated contributions means the sum of all amounts deducted from the compensation of a member together with regular interest credited. 
    Actuarial equivalent means benefits of equivalent actuarial present value. Actuarial equivalencies shall be calculated using such annual rates of compound interest, Group Annuity Mortality Tables and age adjustments as are adopted by the board based upon the advice of the system's actuaries. 
    Beneficiary means any person, except a retirant who is being paid, or has entitlement to, a pension payable by the retirement system. 
    Board means the board of trustees provided in this article. 
    Compensation means the salary or wages paid to a member by the city for personal services rendered to the city by a member. Compensation shall include holiday pay, vacation pay, longevity pay and pay while absent because of illness. Compensation shall not include overtime pay, uniform allowances, equipment allowances, travel allowances, severance payments, redemption of unused sick leave or unused vacation leave and items of a similar nature. If any doubt occurs the board of trustees shall determine whether a payment is compensation for the purpose of this retirement system. For the purpose of applying the limitations set forth in sections 401(a)(17) and 415 of the Internal Revenue Code (IRC), Compensation shall include any elective deferral (as defined in section 402(g)(3) of the IRC), and any amount which is contributed or deferred by the employer at the election of the member and which is not includible in the gross income of the member by reason of section 125 or 457 of the IRC. For limitation years beginning on and after January 1, 2001, for the purposes of applying the limitations described in subsection (a) of section 29-128, compensation paid or made available during such limitation years shall include elective amounts that are not includible in the gross income of the member by reason of section 132(f)(4) of the IRC. 
    Credited service means the number of years and months of continuous uninterrupted service for which the member has received compensation or is entitled to compensation from the date of employment to the date of termination. 
    Final average compensation means 1/96 of the total compensation paid a member during the period of 96 consecutive months of credited service producing the highest total. In the event a member who is employed by the city and not participating in the DROP on September 30, 2011 separates from city employment prior to attaining 96 consecutive months of credited service, final average compensation shall be determined by dividing the total compensation paid by the number of months and fraction thereof of credited service. Provided, in no event shall a member's final average compensation be less than 1/36 of the total compensation paid a member during the period of 36 consecutive months of service producing the highest total prior to October 1, 2011. 
    Former plan means the group annuity retirement program established by the city in December, 1953 and evidenced by group annuity contract GL-163 issued by The Life Insurance Company of Virginia. 
    Management employee means any employee of the city who is a direct management report to the city manager or city council. 
    Member means any person who is included in the membership of the retirement system. 
    Pension means a monthly amount payable by the retirement system throughout the future life of a person or for a temporary period, as provided by this article. 
    Regular interest means such rate of interest per annum, compounded annually, as the board shall adopt. 
    Resolution means a resolution or motion adopted by a majority vote of the board of trustees. 
    Retirant means any member who retires and is being paid or has entitlement to a pension payable by the retirement system on account of employment by the city. 
    Retirement means a member's withdrawal from the employ of the city with entitlement to a pension payable by the retirement system. 
    Retirement system or system means the city retirement system established by this article. 
    Service means personal service rendered to the city by an officer or employee of the city. 
(Code 1957, § 18-22; Code 1994, § 50-187; Ord. No. 94-7161, § 1, 4-6-1994; Ord. No. 94-7240, § 1, 8-3-1994; Ord. No. 99-8642, § 1, 9-15-1999; Ord. No. 10-12676, § 1, 5-19-2010; Ord. No. 11-12951, § 2, 9-21-2011) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Secs. 29-68-29-80. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - BOARD OF TRUSTEES[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference- Boards and commissions, § 2-401 et seq.; appointments of staff members to boards and commissions of the city by the city manager, § 2-407. 

Sec. 29-81. - Authority and responsibility; composition. 
(a)  The authority and responsibility for the general administration and management of the retirement system and for construing and making effective this article is vested in a board of trustees. The board shall consist of 7 trustees, as follows: 
(1)  One member of the city council or a resident of the City of Naples with pension experience or expertise in finance to be appointed by the city council. 
(2)  One resident of the city with pension experience to be appointed by the city council. 
(3)  One member of the administrative staff, also to be a member of the pension plan, to be appointed by the city manager. 
(4)  One nonbargaining unit member to be appointed by the city manager. 
(5)  One bargaining unit member to be appointed by the city manager from a list of 3 bargaining unit members submitted by the president of the bargaining unit. 
(6)  One retiree, currently receiving benefits from the general employees retirement system, to be selected by the current board of trustee members. 
(7)  One resident of the city with expertise in financial markets, to be selected by the current board of trustee members. 
(b)  Notwithstanding any other section of this Code, but subject to any provisions of the state constitution or general law, members of this board shall be permitted to serve on any other board duly formed by the city. 
(c)  Members of the board of trustees shall discharge all duties: 
(1)  Solely in the interest of the participants and beneficiaries of the retirement system; 
(2)  For the exclusive purpose of providing benefits to participants and beneficiaries; 
(3)  With the care, skill, prudence, and diligence that a prudent person acting in a like capacity and familiar with such matters would use in the conduct of an enterprise of a like character with like goals; 
(4)  By diversifying investments of the retirement system in a manner that minimizes the risk of large losses unless, under the circumstances, it is clearly not prudent to do so; and 
(5)  In accordance with documents, instruments, ordinances, and statutes governing the retirement system. 
(Code 1957, § 18-23; Code 1994, § 50-201; Ord. No. 98-8248, § 1, 5-20-1998; Ord. No. 99-8642, § 1, 9-15-1999; Ord. No. 04-10442, § 2, 4-21-2004; Ord. No. 14-13450, § 1, 4-16-2014 ) 
Sec. 29-82. - Term of office; oath of office. 
(a)  The regular term of office of the trustees provided in section 29-81(a) shall be 4 years. 
(b)  Each trustee shall qualify by taking an oath of office before the city clerk prior to assuming the duties of trustee. 
(Code 1957, § 18-24; Code 1994, § 50-202; Ord. No. 99-8642, § 1, 9-15-1999) 
Sec. 29-83. - Vacancies. 
    The office of trustee of the retirement system board of trustees shall be deemed to be vacated by a trustee provided in section 29-81(a)(2) and (3) if the trustee either resigns from the office of trustee or fails to attend 3 consecutive meetings of the board, unless in each case excused for cause by the trustees attending the meeting. The office of trustee shall be deemed to be vacated by a trustee provided in section 29-81(a)(1) if the trustee ceases to be a councilmember of the city. The office of trustee shall be deemed to be vacated by a trustee provided in section 29-81(a)(3) if the trustee ceases to be a member or ceases to be employed by the city in a position covered by the retirement system. If a vacancy occurs in the position of trustee, the vacancy shall be filled by the same means as the former trustee was selected within 90 days for the unexpired portion of the term. 
(Code 1957, § 18-25; Code 1994, § 50-203; Ord. No. 99-8642, § 1, 9-15-1999) 
Sec. 29-84. - Meetings, compensation. 
    The board of trustees of the retirement system shall hold meetings regularly, at least once in each calendar quarter, and shall designate the time and place thereof. It shall adopt its own rules of procedure and shall keep a record of its proceedings. All meetings of the board shall be public. The trustees shall serve without compensation for their services as trustees but shall be entitled to reimbursement of reasonable and necessary expenses incurred, subject to maximum amount and procedures established by the board. 
(Code 1957, § 18-26; Code 1994, § 50-204; Ord. No. 99-8642, § 1, 9-15-1999) 
Sec. 29-85. - Quorum; vote. 
    Four trustees of the retirement system board of trustees shall constitute a quorum at any meeting of the board. Each trustee shall be entitled to 1 vote on each question before the board, and at least 4 concurring votes shall be necessary for a decision by the board. 
(Code 1957, § 18-27; Code 1994, § 50-205; Ord. No. 99-8642, § 1, 9-15-1999) 
Sec. 29-86. - Officers. 
(a)  The board of trustees of the retirement system shall annually elect from its own number a chairman and a vice-chairman. 
(b)  The city clerk or representative shall be secretary to the board and shall be the administrative officer of the retirement system unless another secretary or administrative officer is designated by the board. 
(c)  The finance director shall be treasurer of the retirement system and the custodian of its assets unless another custodian is designated by the board. All payments from the assets of the system shall be made only upon evidence of a specific or continuing board authorization for such payments. 
(d)  The city attorney may give advice to the board of trustees in all matters pertaining to its duties in the general administration and management of the retirement system whenever requested, and may represent and defend the board as its attorney in all suits and actions at law or in equity that may be brought against it and bring all suits or actions in its behalf that may be required or determined by the board. However, the board of trustees, in its discretion, may employ separate and independent legal counsel for such purposes, at the sole cost and expense of the board. 
(e)  The board shall appoint an actuary or firm of actuaries who shall be the technical advisor to the board on matters regarding the operation of the retirement system on an actuarial basis and who shall perform such other related duties as are required by the board. The term "actuary" as used in this article shall mean a member of the American Academy of Actuaries. 
(f)  When needed the board shall appoint as medical director a physician who is not eligible for membership in the retirement system. The medical director shall be responsible to and shall hold office at the pleasure of the board; shall arrange for and pass upon all medical examinations required under this article; shall investigate all essential statements and certificates of a medical nature made by or on behalf of a member, retirant or beneficiary in connection with a claim for disability or death benefits; and shall report in writing to the board conclusions on medical matters referred by the board. 
(g)  The board may employ such professional and other services required for the proper operation of the retirement system. 
(Code 1957, § 18-28; Code 1994, § 50-206; Ord. No. 97-7997, § 1, 6-18-1997; Ord. No. 99-8642, § 1, 9-15-1999) 
Secs. 29-87-29-110. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - MEMBERSHIP AND BENEFITS 

Sec. 29-111. - Membership. 
(a)  The membership of the retirement system shall include all persons who are in the employ of the city and all persons who become employed by the city, except as provided in subsection (b) of this section. 
(b)  The membership of the retirement system shall not include the following: 
(1)  Any person whose service to the city is rendered on a contractual or fee basis, with the exception of the city attorney who may be on a fulltime basis with the city; 
(2)  Any person employed in a position normally requiring less than 20 hours work in a week (part-time); 
(3)  Any person employed in a position normally requiring less than six months work in a year (temporary and seasonal); 
(4)  Any person who is covered under another retirement program supported in whole or in part by monies of the city, except the federal old-age survivors, disability and health insurance program; or 
(5)  The mayor or members of the city council. Any person who was on the city council and whose pension has vested prior to the effective date of Ordinance No. 86-5080 may withdraw, upon request, the accumulated contributions of such person. 
(6)  Any person hired on or after March 1, 1995 otherwise eligible for membership in the retirement system, who has not yet completed six months employment with the city. 
(c)  Should any member leave the employ of the city, the member shall thereupon cease to be a member. 
(d)  If any doubt occurs as to the membership status of any person, the board shall decide the question within the meaning of this article. 
(e)  Notwithstanding any provision in this section 29-11 to the contrary, management employees who are members of this retirement system, employed by the city and not participating in the DROP on September 30, 2011 may elect to discontinue participation in this system and participate in the defined contribution plan. Such election must be made in writing on a form provided by the city no later than October 31, 2011. Any management employee member who does not timely elect to discontinue participating in this retirement system shall continue participating in this system and shall not participate in the defined contribution plan. 
(Code 1957, § 18-30; Code 1994, § 50-231; Ord. No. 95-7379, § 5, 3-1-1995; Ord. No. 98-8247, § 1, 5-20-1998; Ord. No. 99-8642, § 1, 9-15-1999; Ord. No. 11-12951, § 3, 9-21-2011) 
Sec. 29-112. - Credited service. 
(a)  The service rendered by a member in a position covered by the retirement system shall be credited a member by the board in accordance with such rules as the board shall adopt consistent with this article. In no case shall more than one year of service be credited any member for service rendered in any one year. 
(b)  A person's credited service shall be forfeited and no longer in force if the member's accumulated contributions are withdrawn from the system. If a person is reemployed by the city in a position covered by the retirement system and again becomes a member, the member may restore the credited service forfeited by the member by repaying into the system the amount of accumulated contributions withdrawn therefrom, together with regular interest from the date of withdrawal to the date of deposit, subject to the following conditions: 
(1)  The member acquires at least one year of credited service on account of service rendered following such reemployment. 
(2)  The member enters into a repayment agreement with the board and completes repayment within three years of the date of the agreement. 
(c)  Any member who, while employed by the city, was called to or entered or is called to or enters any armed service of the United States and who has been or shall be on active duty in such armed service during time of war or period of compulsory military service shall have such armed service actually required of the member credited the member as city service subject to the following conditions: 
(1)  Is reemployed by the city within the period provided by state or federal law. 
(2)  Returns to the system all amounts withdrawn therefrom at the time of entry or while in such armed service, together with regular interest from the date of withdrawal to the date of repayment. 
(3)  In no case shall more than five years of credited service be given for all such armed service rendered by a member. 
    If any doubt occurs as to the period to be so credited, any member of the board shall have final power to determine such period. During the period of such armed service and until reemployment by the city, contributions to the retirement system shall be suspended. The city may elect to continue the city's contribution to the retirement system upon approval by the retirement board. 
(d)  Service recognized and in force under another retirement program supported in whole or in part by monies of the city shall be recognized as credited service under this retirement system for the limited purpose only of meeting the service requirements of this system. In no case shall such service be used for the purpose of determining the amount of any pension paid by this system. 
(e)  Any member who declined to participate in the retirement program evidenced by group annuity contract GL-163, issued by The Life Insurance Company of Virginia, or who withdrew contributions therefrom shall have the right, prior to January 1, 1974, to enter into an agreement with the board to deposit in the members' savings fund the amounts the member would have contributed pursuant to such retirement program, together with regular interest from the dates the contributions would have been made to the date of deposit. Upon completion of such deposit, the member shall be given credited service for city service prior to January 1, 1973, in positions covered by the retirement system. Otherwise, any such member shall not be given credited service for service rendered prior to January 1, 1973. 
(f)  Any member who was a participant on December 31, 1972, in the retirement program evidenced by group annuity contract GL-163, issued by The Life Insurance Company of Virginia, shall not be granted credited service for city service prior to January 1, 1973, in positions covered by the retirement system until the member has signed any requested waiver of rights under such group annuity contract. 
(Code 1957, § 18-31; Code 1994, § 50-232; Ord. No. 99-8642, § 1, 9-15-1999) 
Sec. 29-113. - Voluntary retirement. 
(a)  Any member of the retirement system hired prior to October 1, 2011 who attains age 55 years and has five or more years credited service in force may retire upon written application filed with the board, setting forth the first day of the calendar month of the desired retirement date. Upon retirement, the member shall be paid a pension provided in. Any member hired prior to October 1, 2011 whose combination of age and years of credited service or fractions thereof equals a total of 85 years, shall be eligible for retirement benefits with no penalty for early retirement. 
(b)  Any member of the retirement system hired on or after October 1, 2011 who attains age 65 years with eight or more years of credited service, or 33 years of credited service regardless of age, may retire upon written application filed with the board, setting forth the first day of the calendar month of the desired retirement date. Upon retirement, the member shall be paid a pension in section 29-115. 
(Code 1957, § 18-32; Code 1994, § 50-233; Ord. No. 95-7379, § 1, 3-1-1995; Ord. No. 98-8247, § 2, 5-20-1998; Ord. No. 99-8642, § 1, 9-15-1999; Ord. No. 11-12951, § 4, 9-21-2011; Ord. No. 12-13142, § 2, 6-13-2012 ) 
Sec. 29-114. - Deferred retirement (vesting). 
(a)  A member hired prior to October 1, 2011 who: 
(1)  Terminates all city employment in positions covered by all the city's retirement systems, for a reason other than retirement or death; and 
(2)  Has five years of credited service in force; shall be entitled to a lump-sum distribution of the member's accumulated contributions, plus an amount equal to the accumulated contributions that would have existed had the member contributed at the rate contributed by the city; and 
(3)  Has and maintains ten or more years of credited service in force; or, has maintained five or more years of credited service in force and has attained the age of 50 years; 
shall be entitled to a deferred pension computed according to section 29-115 as the section was in force at the time the member left such city employment, except as otherwise provided herein. Retirement and payment of the member's pension shall begin the first day of the calendar month next following the month in which the member files a written application therefor with the board, but in no case shall payment begin prior to the first day of the calendar month next following the month in which the member attains age 60 years. Entitlement to a deferred pension shall be forfeited if the member withdraws accumulated contributions from the members' savings fund. Except as specifically otherwise provided in this article, the member shall in no case receive credited service for the period of absence from city employment in a position covered by the retirement system. The deferred member shall also have the option to receive a reduced benefit commencing at age 55 and computed according to section 29-115. 
(b)  A member hired on or after October 1, 2011 who terminates city employment with eight or more years of credited service for a reason other than retirement or death shall be entitled to a deferred pension computed in accordance with section 29-115. Retirement and payment of the member's pension shall begin the first day of the calendar month next following the month in which the member files a written application therefore with the board, but in no case shall payment begin prior to the first day of the calendar month next following the month in which the member attains age 65 or 33 years of credited service. Entitlement to a deferred pension shall be forfeited if the member withdraws accumulated contributions from the members' savings fund. Except as specifically otherwise provided in this article, the member shall in no case receive credited service for the period of absence from city employment in a position covered by the retirement system. The deferred member shall also have the option to receive a reduced benefit commencing at age 55 and computed in accordance with section 29-115. 
(c)  Members are eligible to receive funds from the plan at termination of employment with the city. Upon termination, employee is eligible to receive all employee contributions and the vested balance in employer contributions as identified in section 29-152. Members are eligible to receive a cash distribution of funds, subject to regulations of the Internal Revenue Service, a direct rollover, an annuity through the plan administrator, or funds may be left in the plan to a future date, subject to Internal Revenue Service regulations. 
(Code 1957, § 18-34; Code 1994, § 50-234; Ord. No. 95-7379, § 2, 3-1-1995; Ord. No. 11-12951, § 5, 9-21-2011) 
Sec. 29-115. - Pension amount. 
(a)  Upon retirement as provided in this article, a member or former member shall be paid a level straight life pension terminating upon death or may elect, within the 90-day period immediately preceding or the 20-day period immediately following the date retirement begins, to be paid a pension under an optional form of payment provided in section 29-116 in lieu of a level straight life pension. 
(b)  Subject to subsections (c) and (e) of this section, the amount of a member's straight life pension shall be equal to two percent of the member's final average compensation multiplied by the member's credited service. The straight life pension for a member with credited service subsequent to January 1, 1998, who retires subsequent to January 31, 1998, subject to subsection (c) of this section, shall be equal to two and one-quarter percent of the member's final average compensation multiplied by the member's credited service. The straight life pension for a member on or subsequent to January 1, 2000, who retires on or subsequent to January 1, 2000, subject to subsections (c) and (e) of this section, shall be equal to two and one-half percent of the member's final average compensation multiplied by the member's credited service. The straight life pension for a member who retires on or after October 1, 2011, subject to subsections (c), (d) and (e) below, shall be equal to two and one-half percent of the member's final average compensation multiplied by the member's credited service earned prior to October 1, 2011, and 1.6 percent of the member's final average compensation multiplied by the member's credited service earned on or after October 1, 2011. A member's straight life pension shall not exceed a maximum of 100 percent of the member's final average compensation, not including any scheduled periodic or one-time cost-of-living benefit increases. The amount of the monthly pension being paid to any retirant or beneficiary who was receiving such benefit prior to January 1, 2000 shall be increased, effective March 1, 2000, to $25.00 per month. 
(c)  If a member hired prior to October 1, 2011 retires pursuant to section 29-113 prior to the first day of the calendar month in which the member attains age 60 years, the amount of the member's level straight life pension shall be reduced by 0.25 percent multiplied by the number of months and fraction of a month in the period from the date of the member's retirement to the date the member would attain age 60 years. 
(d)  If a member hired on or after October 1, 2011 retires pursuant to section 29-113 prior to the first day of the calendar month in which the member attains age 65, the amount of the member's level straight life pension shall be reduced by 0.25 percent multiplied by the number of months and fraction of a month in the period from the date of the member's retirement to the date the member would attain age 65 years. 
(e)  Notwithstanding any other provision of this Article III, effective September 30, 2011, the accrued benefits of all members who are employed by the city and not participating in the DROP on that date shall be frozen. The value of each such member's frozen accrued benefit shall be calculated in accordance with subsection (b), above, and such frozen accrued benefit shall be payable to the member upon separation from city employment and attaining age 60 with five or more years of credited service, or the date on which a member's age to last completed month plus credited service totals 85 years or more, and the member has five or more years of credited service. For credited service on and after October 1, 2011, the benefit formula for all members shall be 1.6 percent of average final compensation multiplied by years of credited service on and after that date. 
(f)  Notwithstanding any other provision of this Article III, members who are employed by the city and not participating in the DROP on September 30, 2011 shall, upon retirement, be eligible to receive a retirement benefit consisting of two parts: (1) the frozen accrued benefit based on credited service prior to October 1, 2011, and the provisions of the retirement system in effect on September 29, 2011; and (2) the accrued benefit based on credited service on and after October 1, 2011, and the provisions of this Article III, as amended effective September 30, 2011; payable at age 60 with five or more years of credited service, or the date on which a member's age to last completed month plus credited service totals 85 years or more and the member has five or more years of credited service, whichever occurs first. 
(Code 1957, § 18-35; Code 1994, § 50-235; Ord. No. 95-7379, §§ 3, 6, 3-1-1995; Ord. No. 98-8247, § 3, 5-20-1998; Ord. No. 99-8642, § 1, 9-15-1999; Ord. No. 00-8777, § 1, 2-16-2000; Ord. No. 11-12951, § 6, 9-21-2011) 
Sec. 29-116. - Optional forms of payment. 
    Within the 90-day period immediately preceding or the 20-day period immediately following the date retirement begins, a member or former member may elect to be paid a pension under one of the optional forms of payment listed in this section in lieu of a level straight life pension. The amount of an optional form of pension payment shall be the actuarial equivalent of the amount of the level straight life pension. If a member or former member does not make a timely election of an optional form of payment, the member shall be paid a level straight life pension. The optional forms of payment shall be as follows: 
(1)  Option A, joint and survivor pension. Under option A, a retirant shall be paid a reduced pension throughout the retirant's life, with the provision that, upon death, the retirant's full reduced pension shall be continued throughout the future life of and paid to such person, having an insurable interest in the retirant's life, as a retirant shall have nominated by written designation duly executed and filed with the board at the time of election of option A. 
(2)  Option B, modified joint and survivor pension. Under option B, a retirant shall be paid a reduced pension throughout a retirant's life, with the provision that, upon death, 1/2 of the retirant's reduced pension shall be continued throughout the future life of and paid to such person, having an insurable interest in the retirant's life, as the retirant shall have nominated by written designation duly executed and filed with the board at the time of election of option B. 
(3)  Option C, social security integrated pension. Under option C, a retirant shall be paid an increased pension to the attainment of social security retirement benefits and a reduced pension thereafter. The increased pension shall approximate the sum of the reduced pension payable thereafter and the estimated social security primary insurance amount. This option shall be available only to: 
a.  Former members who retire pursuant to section 29-114; and 
b.  Members who retire on or after age 60 years pursuant to section 29-113. 
(4)  Option D, lump sum payment. Where a retirant or beneficiary is entitled to a pension, the monthly amount of which is computed to be $250.00 or less per month, the retirant or beneficiary, upon proof of good health, satisfactory to the board, may elect to receive or the board may elect to pay a lump sum payout. 
(5)  Option E, 10-year certain payout. A retirant may elect to receive a pension benefit paid out in equal monthly installments over a 10-year period and life thereafter; should the retirant die before the expiration of the 10-year period, the balance of the 10-year benefit shall be paid to the retirant's designated beneficiary. 
(Code 1957, § 18-36; Code 1994, § 50-236; Ord. No. 99-8642, § 1, 9-15-1999) 
Sec. 29-117. - Refund of accumulated contributions. 
(a)  If a member of the retirement system ceases to be employed by the city for any reason except retirement or death before attainment of age 60 years with five or more years of credited service in force, the member shall be paid their accumulated contributions, plus an amount equal to the accumulated contributions that would have existed had the member contributed at the rate contributed by the city, upon written request filed with the board. 
(b)  If a member dies and no pension becomes or will become payable on account of death, the member's accumulated contributions shall be paid to such person as the member shall have nominated by written designation duly executed and filed with the board. If there is no such designated person surviving the member, these accumulated contributions shall be paid to the member's legal representative. 
(c)  Effective October 1, 2006, if an actively employed member has completed at least five years and six months of credited service at the time of death, the designated person or legal representative shall receive 100 percent of the contributions made to the plan for that member by the city, in addition to a refund of 100 percent of the member's contributions with regular interest. 
(d)  If a retirant and option A or option B beneficiary, if any, die before they have been paid an aggregate amount of pension equal to the member's accumulated contributions at the time of the member's retirement, the difference between the member's accumulated contributions and the aggregate amount of pension paid shall be paid to such person as the member shall have nominated by written designation duly executed and filed with the board. If there is no such designated person surviving the retirant and an option A or option B beneficiary, such difference shall be paid to the legal representative of the last to die of the retirant and an option A or option B beneficiary. 
(e)  Payment of refunds of accumulated contributions as provided in this section may be made in a single sum or in installments, as provided by the board. 
(Code 1957, § 18-41; Code 1994, § 50-239; Ord. No. 99-8642, § 1, 9-15-1999; Ord. No. 07-11740, § 1, 8-15-2007) 
Sec. 29-118. - Members' contributions. 
(a)  A member's contributions to the retirement system shall be five percent of the member's individual compensation. Notwithstanding the preceding sentence, members of the bargaining unit represented by the Government Supervisors Association of Florida, Office and Professional Employees International Union (GSAF), Local 100, AFL-CIO, shall contribute ten and one-half percent of the member's individual compensation to the retirement system, effective October 1, 2009 through September 30, 2011; and five percent thereafter for members hired prior to October 1, 2011. For members hired on or after October 1, 2011 the member contribution to the retirement system shall be three percent of the member's individual compensation. 
(b)  The officer responsible for making up the payroll shall cause the contributions provided in this section to be deducted from the compensation of each member on each and every payroll, for each and every payroll period, so long as the member is a member of the retirement system. The members' contributions shall be made notwithstanding that the minimum compensation provided by law for any member shall be changed thereby. Every member shall be deemed to consent and agree to the deductions made and provided in this section. Each of such amounts shall be deducted and when deducted shall be paid to the retirement system and shall be credited to the member's accumulated contributions. 
(c)  Notwithstanding any section in this article, any member may contribute to a voluntary deferred compensation (IRC section 457) plan in addition to participating in this retirement system. 
(Code 1957, § 18-42; Code 1994, § 50-240; Ord. No. 95-7379, § 4, 3-1-1995; Ord. No. 98-8247, § 5, 5-20-1998; Ord. No. 99-8642, § 1, 9-15-1999; Ord. No. 03-10213, § 1, 10-1-2003; Ord. No. 04-10442, § 3, 4-21-2004; Ord. No. 05-10758, § 1, 2-16-2005; Ord. No. 07-11740, § 2, 8-15-2007; Ord. No. 09-12514, § 1, 9-16-2009; Ord. No. 11-12951, § 7, 9-21-2011) 
Sec. 29-119. - City contribution fund; city contributions. 
(a)  The financial objective of this article is to provide for annual city contributions which, expressed as percents of member payroll, will remain approximately level from generation to generation of city taxpayers. Such contribution rates shall be sufficient, together with member contributions to: 
(1)  Fully cover the value of benefit commitments being made to members for their service being rendered in the current year; and 
(2)  To fully cover the unfunded value of benefit commitments for service rendered prior to the current year over a period of not more than 30 future years. 
(b)  The city contribution amount shall be determined within the objective of subsection (a) of this section by annual actuarial valuations based on such mortality and other tables of experience and regular interest as the board shall adopt. The city contributions so determined shall be certified to the city by the board and shall be appropriated and paid to the retirement system. 
(Code 1957, § 18-43; Code 1994, § 50-241; Ord. No. 99-8642, § 1, 9-15-1999) 
Sec. 29-120. - Investment of assets. 
    The board shall be the trustees of the assets of the retirement system and shall have full and unrestricted discretionary power and authority to invest and reinvest the assets of the system. The board shall have full and unrestricted discretionary power and authority to hold, sell, assign, transfer or otherwise dispose of any securities and investments in which any monies of the retirement system have been invested, as well as the proceeds of such investments and monies belonging to the retirement system, and may delegate this authority to one or more investment managers, who shall acknowledge in writing that they are named fiduciaries with respect to the retirement system within the meaning of F.S. § 112.656 and who shall invest the retirement system's assets in accordance with this article, applicable federal and state laws and regulations, and investment guidelines adopted by the board. The board shall identify and publicly report any direct or indirect holdings it may have in any scrutinized company, as defined in F.S. § 215.473, and proceed to sell, redeem, divest, or withdraw all publicly traded securities it may have in such company beginning January 1, 2010 and shall thereafter be prohibited from purchasing or holding such securities. The divestiture of any such security must be completed by September 30, 2010. In accordance with Ch. 2009-97, Laws of Florida, no person may bring any civil, criminal, or administrative action against the board or any employee, officer, director, or advisor of such board based upon the divestiture of any security pursuant to this paragraph. Within the limitation of such standard, investments may be made in, specifically including but not by way of limitation, obligations of the United States government and in obligations guaranteed as to principal and interest by the United States government, in corporate notes, bonds or debentures, convertible or otherwise, in equipment trust certificates and in loans secured by first mortgages or deeds of trust on real property and such investments may be made without limitation as to the percentage of the book value of the assets so invested. Investments may also be made in either common or preferred corporate stocks. In no event shall more than five percent of the assets of the retirement system, be invested in the securities of any one corporation nor shall the retirement system acquire or hold more than five percent of the outstanding stock or bonds of any one corporation. 
(Code 1957, § 18-46; Code 1994, § 50-242; Ord. No. 99-8642, § 1, 9-15-1999; Ord. No. 10-12676, § 2, 5-19-2010) 
Sec. 29-121. - Assets not segregated. 
    All assets of the retirement system shall be held in an irrevocable trust which is hereby created for the sole purpose of meeting disbursements for pensions and other payments authorized by the board pursuant to this article and shall be used for no other purpose. 
(Code 1957, § 18-47; Code 1994, § 50-243; Ord. No. 99-8642, § 1, 9-15-1999) 
Sec. 29-122. - Allowance of regular interest. 
    The board shall, at the end of each fiscal year, allow and credit regular interest to the members' accumulated contributions. 
(Code 1957, § 18-48; Code 1994, § 50-244; Ord. No. 99-8642, § 1, 9-15-1999) 
Sec. 29-123. - Method of making payments. 
    All payments from monies of the retirement system shall be made by the finance director or by a custodian or funding agent designated by the board. Such payments shall be made only upon the written authority signed by two persons designated by the board. A duly attested copy of a resolution designating such persons and bearing upon its face specimen signatures of such persons shall be filed with the finance director or the funding agent. No such written authority to make payments from the monies of the system shall be executed unless the payments shall have been previously authorized by a specific or continuing resolution adopted by the board. 
(Code 1957, § 18-49; Code 1994, § 50-245; Ord. No. 99-8642, § 1, 9-15-1999) 
Sec. 29-124. - Assignments prohibited. 
    The right of a person to a pension, to the return of accumulated contributions, the pension itself, any optional benefit, any other right accrued or accruing to any person under this article and the monies belonging to the retirement system shall not be subject to execution, garnishment, attachment, the operation of bankruptcy or insolvency law or any other process of law whatsoever and shall be unassignable except as is specifically provided in this article, provided that the city shall have the right of setoff for any claim arising from embezzlement by or fraud of a member, retirant or beneficiary. 
(Code 1957, § 18-50; Code 1994, § 50-246; Ord. No. 99-8642, § 1, 9-15-1999) 
Sec. 29-125. - Insurance coverage. 
    If a member of the retirement system is covered under a group insurance or prepayment plan participated in by the city and should be permitted to and elect to continue such coverage as a retirant, the member may authorize the board to have deducted from any pension the payments required to continue coverage under such group insurance or prepayment plan, which the system shall transmit on the member's behalf to the city or its designee. 
(Code 1957, § 18-51; Code 1994, § 50-247; Ord. No. 99-8642, § 1, 9-15-1999) 
Sec. 29-126. - Errors. 
    Should the board determine that any person is receiving from the retirement system more or less than they are entitled to receive, the board shall correct such error and as far as practicable shall adjust the payment in such manner that the actuarial equivalent of the benefit to which the person was correctly entitled shall be paid. 
(Code 1957, § 18-53; Code 1994, § 50-248; Ord. No. 99-8642, § 1, 9-15-1999) 
Sec. 29-127. - Former plan minimum; offset.
