(3)  No person shall discharge or throw overboard any oil, fuel, spirits, oily bilge, sewage, or any other foreign material into Naples Bay. 
(4)  Any vessel moored in the anchorage may be inspected at any time by the dockmaster or a U.S. Coast Guard representative for safety or sanitary purposes. 
(5)  All vessels permitted to use the anchorage shall be equipped with an approved and properly operating marine sanitation device. The dockmaster shall have authority to inspect the device and require a vessel to use the wastewater pumpout facility before assigning a mooring and the dockmaster shall have the authority to require periodic pumpout if the vessel remains moored for more than one week. 
(6)  Assignment of a mooring shall constitute permission for the vessel's inhabitants to use the dinghy dock, deposit trash and garbage in the appropriate containers, use the laundry and toilet/lavatory/shower facilities on the city dock, use the dockmaster's bicycles, use the potable water supply, and otherwise enjoy the benefits assigned city dock tenants. 
(7)  Graywater discharge shall be kept to a minimum. The laundry machines at the city dock must be used for clothes washing. 
(8)  Noise shall be kept at a minimum at all times so as to avoid creation of a nuisance or disturbance. The anchorage is in a residential neighborhood and subsections 22-37(d), (e), (h) and (j) apply to waterways as well as ashore. 
(9)  No painting, scraping, sanding, or other repairs shall be permitted in the anchorage except such repairs and maintenance as may be authorized by the dockmaster. 
(10)  The dockmaster is responsible for the enforcement of the rules and regulations for the city dock/Crayton Cove anchorage and may terminate the mooring agreement and order any vessel to vacate the assigned mooring for violation of any rule or regulation relating to the anchorage. At the dockmaster's discretion, the following enforcement for violations of the rules and regulations relating to the city dock/Crayton Cove anchorage shall be provided: 
a.  Verbal warning issued by the dockmaster to the offender, with documentation in the dockmaster's file; 
b.  Written warning depending of the severity of the violation (the dockmaster will provide written notice to the offender detailing the violation); 
c.  Notice to appear in the county court; and 
d.  Termination of the mooring agreement. If the vessel owner or operator cannot be located after termination of the agreement, the vessel shall be towed from the anchorage to a commercial marina for storage at the owner's expense. The mooring rental rate shall be quadrupled until the vessel is towed from the anchorage. 
In addition to the procedure dealing with enforcement of the violations at the city dock/Crayton Cove anchorage, the city will provide a hearing and appeals procedure for violation of rules and regulations of the city dock/Crayton Cove anchorage, as follows: Within ten days of the notice of violation the offender may file a written notice of intent to appeal the dockmaster's decision with the city manager, whereby a hearing will be scheduled within five days with the city manager. The decision of the city manager will be final. 
(Code 1994, § 78-111; Ord. No. 00-8820, § 1, 5-3-2000) 
Sec. 42-144. - Mooring rental rate. 
    The city council shall, by resolution, set the daily rental rate for the 12 moorings in the city dock/Crayton Cove anchorage. The rate shall be posted in the dockmaster's office and on the signs at the east ends of the anchorage areas, and shall be as set forth in appendix A to this Code. 
(Code 1994, § 78-112; Ord. No. 00-8820, § 1, 5-3-2000; Res. No. 17-14057 , § 1, 11-1-2017) 
Sec. 42-145. - Moorings signage. 
    To ensure compliance with the rules and regulations for the city dock/Crayton Cove anchorage, a single sign shall be placed at the east end of each anchorage area. The signs shall be four feet high by six feet wide and shall display the following wording: "MANAGED ANCHORAGE," "ALL VESSELS MUST USE MOORING BUOYS," "FOR MOORING ASSIGNMENT REGISTER AT THE DOCKMASTER'S OFFICE ON THE CITY DOCK," "$_____ PER DAY MOORING RENTAL FEE." Beneath those lines the sign shall also state that the anchorage is managed under an agreement with the trustees of the internal improvement trust fund and reference the agreement number. 
(Code 1994, § 78-113; Ord. No. 00-8820, § 1, 5-3-2000) 
Secs. 42-146-42-170. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - BOATS[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference- Department of police and emergency services, § 2-281 et seq.; parks and recreation, ch. 28. 
State Law reference- Vessels, F.S. ch. 327. 

Sec. 42-171. - Definitions. 
    All definitions pertaining to this article that are defined in either general law or the Florida Administrative Code concerning vessels and marine animals, including specifically those set out in F.S. chs. 327 and 379, and Chapter 68C-22, Florida Administrative Code, as may be amended from time to time, are incorporated in this article and shall be construed in this article in the same manner as in state law. 
(Code 1957, § 7-60; Code 1994, § 78-136; Ord. No. 04-10664, § 1, 11-17-2004; Ord. No. 16-13751 , § 2, 2-3-2016) 
Sec. 42-172. - Boating-restricted areas. 
(a)  The following boating-restricted areas are created in Doctors Pass and the Moorings Bay System, from Seagate Drive south to Banyan Boulevard, and are designated as idle speed no wake boating-restricted areas. No person shall operate a motorboat in any area designated and posted as an idle speed no wake zone at a speed greater than idle speed: 
(1)  Within 500 feet of any boat ramp, hoist, marine railway, or other launching or landing facility available for use by the general boating public on waterways more than 300 feet in width or within 300 feet of any boat ramp, hoist, marine railway, or other launching or landing facility available for use by the general boating public on waterways not exceeding 300 feet in width. 
(2)  Within 500 feet of fuel pumps or dispensers at any marine fueling facility that sells motor fuel to the general boating public on waterways more than 300 feet in width or within 300 feet of the fuel pumps or dispensers at any licensed terminal facility that sells motor fuel to the general boating public on waterways not exceeding 300 feet in width. 
(b)  The following boating-restricted areas are created in Doctors Pass and the Moorings Bay System, from Seagate Drive south to Banyan Boulevard, and are designated as slow speed minimum wake boating-restricted areas. No person shall operate a motorboat in any area designated and posted as a slow speed minimum wake zone at a speed greater than slow speed: 
(1)  Within 300 feet of the Park Shore Drive bridge span. 
(2)  Within 300 feet of the Harbour Drive bridge span. 
(3)  Within 300 feet of the Mooring Line Drive bridge span. 
(Code 1957, § 7-61; Code 1994, § 78-137; Ord. No. 16-13751 , § 3, 2-3-2016; Ord. No. 16-13786 , § 2, 5-4-2016) 
Sec. 42-173. - Exemptions. 
    Restrictions established pursuant to this article shall not apply in the case of an emergency or to a law enforcement, firefighting, or rescue vessel owned or operated by or on behalf of a governmental entity. 
(Code 1957, § 7-66; Code 1994, § 78-138; Ord. No. 16-13751 , § 4, 2-3-2016) 
Sec. 42-174. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 16-13751 , § 5, adopted Feb. 3, 2016, repealed § 42-174 entitled "Careful and prudent operation required", which derived from: Code 1957, § 7-62; and Code 1994, § 78-139. 
Sec. 42-175. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 16-13751 , § 6, adopted Feb. 3, 2016, repealed § 42-175 entitled "Fines", which derived from: Code 1957, § 7-68; Code 1994, § 78-141; Ord. No. 94-7101, § 1, adopted Jan. 5, 1994; and Ord. No. 04-10664, § 1, adopted Nov. 17, 2004. 
Sec. 42-176. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 16-13751 , § 7, adopted Feb. 3, 2016, repealed § 42-176 entitled "Speed generally", which derived from: Code 1957, § 7-11; and Code 1994, § 78-142. 
Sec. 42-177. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 16-13751 , § 8, adopted Feb. 3, 2016, repealed § 42-177 entitled "Speed limit in certain restricted areas", which derived from: Code 1957, § 7-63; Code 1994, § 78-143; and Ord. No. 04-10664, § 1, adopted Nov. 17, 2004. 
Sec. 42-178. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 16-13751 , § 9, adopted Feb. 3, 2016, repealed § 42-178 entitled "Speed greater than is reasonable under conditions", which derived from: Code 1957, § 7-64; Code 1994, § 78-144; and Ord. No. 04-10664, § 1, adopted Nov. 17, 2004. 
Sec. 42-179. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 16-13751 , § 10, adopted Feb. 3, 2016, repealed § 42-179 entitled "Use of searchlights, horns, whistles or bells", which derived from: Code 1957, § 7-19; and Code 1994, § 78-146. 
Sec. 42-180. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 16-13751 , § 11, adopted Feb. 3, 2016, repealed § 42-180 entitled "Garbage disposal", which derived from: Code 1957, § 7-20; and Code 1994, § 78-147. 
Secs. 42-181-42-200. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - CHARTER BOATS[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Cross reference- Businesses, ch. 10. 

Sec. 42-201. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meaning ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Capacity means the maximum number of passengers as listed on the certificate of inspection provided by the Coast Guard. Vessels that do not require a certificate of inspection, or that are not otherwise provided for in this article, are limited to a capacity of six passengers. 
    Charter boat means a vessel offered for hire or rent for periods of time which may or may not include the service of a captain or crew, or both. This includes rental boats, sightseeing boats, ferry boats, head boats, personal watercraft and similar vessels for rent or hire, and "bareboat" charters. Water taxis are excluded from this definition. 
    Landside facility means a location from which restricted charter boats are allowed to receive passengers via public or chartered transportation. 
    Permanent displacement means the dissolution of a charter boat operator's lease, tenancy or ownership from a marina facility without the ability to return to the facility due to closure or redevelopment of the marina facility. 
    Public or chartered transportation means any form of taxi, public bus, hotel van or limousine, or chartered bus. Public or chartered transportation may not utilize parking spaces at a landside facility unless designated parking is identified and approved as part of a landside facility petition. 
    Restricted charter boat means a charter boat which is required to receive passengers via public or chartered transportation at an approved landside facility unless otherwise authorized through an approved landside facility petition. Restricted charter boats are limited to a capacity of eight passengers. See section 42-203 for location and parking requirements. 
    Temporary event charter boat means any charter boat contracted by a single broker or business for a specific group of passengers for a limited period of time not to exceed three days. 
    Temporary unrestricted charter boat means any unrestricted charter boat which has been permanently displaced from a marina facility due to closure or redevelopment of the marina facility and is therefore eligible to maintain status as an unrestricted charter boat until the operator has secured a location for the boat with adequate parking provisions. 
    Unrestricted charter boat means a charter boat which has allocated the required number of on-site parking spaces at its mooring location or at an off-site parking location within 600 feet of the mooring location as approved through the conditional use process. See section 42-203 for location and parking requirements. 
    Water taxi means a vessel offered for hire with a capacity of 12 persons designed to transport passengers to and from properties adjacent to the local waterways. For purposes of permitting, water taxis shall be considered a motor vehicle taxi and shall be required to receive all necessary city council approvals that a motor vehicle taxi is required to receive. 
(Code 1994, § 78-170; Ord. No. 95-7454, § 1, 6-7-1995; Ord. No. 95-7565, § 1, 11-1-1995; Ord. No. 99-8452, § 1, 1-20-1999; Ord. No. 00-8955, § 1, 10-4-2000; Ord. No. 01-9193, § 1, 5-16-2001) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 42-202. - License requirements. 
(a)  Occupational licenses. All charter boats operating within the municipal limits of the city are required by article III of chapter 34 to maintain a current city occupational license. All applicants applying for or renewing an occupational license for a charter boat shall furnish the following information: 
(1)  State of Florida vessel registration; 
(2)  Copy of captain's license (if applicable); 
(3)  Coast Guard certificate of inspection (if applicable); 
(4)  Proof of insurance; 
(5)  Applicants for an unrestricted charter boat or water taxi license shall provide proof of ownership of a mooring slip or a letter of permission from the facility where the boat is moored if the mooring slip is not owned by the applicant; 
(6)  Applicants for a restricted charter boat license shall provide a letter of permission from each landside facility from which the boat will operate. 
(b)  Capacity. Restricted charter boats are limited to a capacity of eight passengers. Water taxis are limited to a capacity of 12 passengers. Unrestricted charter boats are limited by the capacity as defined by the Coast Guard certificate of inspection in conjunction with location and parking requirements. 
(c)  Issuance of registration sticker. A registration sticker shall be issued with each city occupational license, and shall be displayed in a prominent location on the port side of the stern of the charter boat. Failure to display the sticker shall be considered a violation of this Code. 
(d)  Transfer of license requirements. No license shall be transferred without the approval of the city as to the conformance of the proposed change to zoning and other regulations as listed in this Code. Occupational licenses for charter boats are required to be transferred when: 
(1)  Unrestricted charter boats change mooring locations, transfer ownership, change the name of the boat or change to temporary unrestricted charter boat status. The licensee shall apply for and receive the transfer of license prior to making any of the changes listed in this subsection. 
(2)  Restricted charter boats add or change landside facilities, change mooring locations, transfer ownership, or change the name of the boat. The licensee shall apply for and receive the transfer prior to making any of the changes listed in this subsection. 
(e)  Temporary use permits. Operators of temporary event charter boats that are not licensed or moored in the city must obtain a temporary use permit in order to conduct operations within city limits. A temporary use permit may be issued for a period not to exceed three consecutive days. Temporary use permits may be issued a maximum of two times per calendar year per temporary event charter boat. The application process for a temporary event charter boat shall be consistent with the temporary use permit application process pursuant to subsection 46-39(b)(4). Application for a temporary use permit shall be made prior to contracting for or publication of an event. The following documents shall be submitted upon application for a temporary use permit: 
(1)  State of Florida vessel registration; 
(2)  Copy of captain's license; 
(3)  Coast Guard certificate of inspection; 
(4)  Proof of insurance; and 
(5)  A letter of permission from the landside facility from which the boat will operate. 
Charter boats operating with a temporary use permit shall operate only at approved landside facilities, and shall comply with the same location requirements, signage requirements, and publication provisions as restricted charter boats. 
(f)  Temporary unrestricted charter boats. 
(1)  Operators of unrestricted charter boats are eligible for temporary unrestricted charter boat status if the following criteria are met: 
a.  The operator's unrestricted charter boat has been permanently displaced from a mooring location within the city due to the closing or redevelopment of the facility. Upon application for transfer of an occupational license, the operator must provide written evidence to demonstrate permanent dissolution of the operator's lease, tenancy, or ownership due to closing or redevelopment of the facility. The city manager shall validate the written evidence provided. 
b.  The operator has held a city occupational license for an unrestricted charter boat and has operated the unrestricted charter boat for the two consecutive years prior to the permanent dissolution of the operator's lease, tenancy, or ownership from the facility that is to be closed or redeveloped. 
(2)  Temporary unrestricted charter boats shall obtain a transfer of occupational license and shall comply with the same requirements and provisions as unrestricted charter boats with the exception that temporary unrestricted charter boats are not subject to the requirement that one on-site parking space per four passengers of capacity be provided at the mooring location. The capacity of a temporary unrestricted charter boat shall remain the same as the boat's operational capacity at time of displacement. 
(3)  In order to facilitate enforcement of this designation, each temporary unrestricted charter boat shall be issued a city-authorized flag which shall be prominently displayed on the charter boat while in operation. 
(4)  Temporary unrestricted charter boat status is assigned to the operator or corporate operator of a specific boat meeting the above criteria, and is nontransferable from one operator or corporation to another. Temporary unrestricted charter boat status may be transferred by an operator or corporate operator from one boat to another provided the operator or corporate operator has not changed. The status may also be transferred by an operator to a spouse, son or daughter. 
(5)  Temporary unrestricted charter boat status shall expire three years after the initial issuance date of the license. The city manager may authorize an extension for up to two years. Temporary unrestricted charter boat status shall expire for all vessels on January 1, 2008. 
(Code 1994, § 78-171; Ord. No. 95-7454, § 1, 6-7-1995; Ord. No. 95-7565, § 2, 11-1-1995; Ord. No. 00-8955, §§ 2, 3, 10-4-2000; Ord. No. 01-9193, § 1, 5-16-2001; Ord. No. 05-10959, § 1, 9-21-2005) 
Sec. 42-203. - Location and parking requirements. 
(a)  Unrestricted charter boats and water taxis. Unrestricted charter boats and water taxis must be moored at a commercially zoned location where charter boat activity is permitted and shall provide one parking space for every four passengers of capacity either on-site or off-site within 600 feet with conditional use approval. Unrestricted charter boats and water taxis may also receive passengers via public or chartered transportation at any approved landside facility, subject to the requirements of subsection 42-204(b). 
(b)  Restricted charter boats. Operators of restricted charter boats shall only operate at landside facilities for which they have been specifically approved by the city. Passengers shall not park at the landside facility and shall arrive at the landside facility by public or chartered transportation, unless otherwise authorized through an approved landside facility petition. 
(c)  Landside facilities. Landside facilities shall be located in a commercial zoning district where such use is permitted. All landside facilities are required to provide the appropriate number of parking spaces for the number of noncommercial slips and the total capacity of unrestricted charter boats and water taxis moored at the facility on a permanent or transient basis, pursuant to the requirements of section 50-104. 
(d)  Receiving and discharging passengers. Operators of unrestricted and restricted charter boats with a capacity of no more than six passengers may receive and discharge passengers: 
(1)  At the private residence of a passenger on the charter; or 
(2)  At a waterfront hotel with dock access provided the passenger is a registered guest at the hotel and permission is received from the hotel. A hotel granting permission under this section shall keep a permanent register including the date; the names of all unrestricted charter boats, and restricted charter boats receiving passengers at the hotel, the name of the registered guest, the corresponding number of passengers, and the time that passengers embark and return. 
(e)  Unrestricted charter boats moored at the Municipal Dock and temporarily displaced due to redevelopment of the Municipal Dock are allowed to receive and discharge passengers at Naples Landings with the permission of the city manager and in accordance with rules promulgated by the city manager and payment of fees equivalent to the City Dock/Crayton Cove anchorage, mooring rental rate set forth in appendix A - Fees and Charges Schedule. 
(Code 1994, § 78-172; Ord. No. 95-7454, § 1, 6-7-1995; Ord. No. 96-7860, § 1, 11-20-1996; Ord. No. 99-8523, § 1, 4-21-1999; Ord. No. 01-9193, § 1, 5-16-2001; Ord. No. 17-13931 , § 1, 3-1-2017) 
Sec. 42-204. - Landside facilities. 
(a)  Approval of landside facilities. Landside facilities shall receive approval from city council by resolution at an advertised public hearing prior to allowing restricted charter boats to operate from the facility. The city manager shall notify owners of property located within 500 feet of the property involved in the petition, informing them of the date, time, place and reason for the public hearing. Failure to notify all owners of property located within 500 feet by mail will not render any action taken on such petition void. The landside facility shall provide the council with an operating procedure for maintaining the records required by this section, a site plan detailing the mooring location for restricted charter boats and including the arrival/departure point for passengers, and, if applicable, the on-site or off-site parking location for chartered transportation. 
(b)  Record of charter boat activity. Landside facilities shall keep a permanent register of the following: 
(1)  All restricted charter boat activity which occurs at the facility; and 
(2)  All unrestricted charter boat activity which occurs at the facility for unrestricted vessels not permanently moored at the landside facility. The register shall include the date; the names of all restricted charter boats, and unrestricted charter boats receiving passengers via chartered or public transportation, in operation; and the corresponding number of passengers, the time that passengers embark and return, and the means of transportation used by the passengers to arrive at the landside facility. Each register entry shall be signed by the person who entered the information. Failure of the landside facility operator to maintain a permanent register of charter boat activity, including those boats not permanently moored at the facility, shall be considered a violation of the provisions of this Code. 
(c)  Issuance and display of flags for restricted charter boats. In order to facilitate enforcement of this Code, landside facilities shall provide a city-approved flag to each restricted charter boat that operates from the facility. The flag shall be issued by the landside facility to the operator of the charter boat when picking up passengers at the facility, and shall be prominently displayed on the charter boat while in operation. The operator of the charter boat shall return the flag to the landside facility when returning passengers to the facility. The flag shall only be displayed while a restricted charter boat is operating a charter from a landside facility. 
(Code 1994, § 78-173; Ord. No. 95-7454, § 1, 6-7-1995; Ord. No. 96-7860, § 2, 11-20-1996; Ord. No. 99-8615, § 1, 9-1-1999; Ord. No. 01-9193, § 1, 5-16-2001) 
Sec. 42-205. - Signage requirements for charter boats and water taxis. 
(a)  Generally. Charter boats and water taxis with a base of operation from a commercial land point within the municipal limits of the city are permitted to have signage on the vessel including painting or wrap of the vessel itself. 
(b)  Unrestricted charter boats. Unrestricted charter boats shall be permitted one additional sign, to be posted at the mooring slip, and not to exceed a maximum of 16 square feet. 
(c)  Restricted charter boats. Restricted charter boats are not permitted additional signage at their mooring location or landside facility. 
(Code 1994, § 78-174; Ord. No. 95-7454, § 1, 6-7-1995; Ord. No. 99-8584, § 1, 8-4-1999; Ord. No. 01-9193, § 1, 5-16-2001; Ord. No. 12-13169, § 1, 9-19-2012 ) 
Sec. 42-206. - Advertising provisions for restricted charter boats. 
    In order to control the violation of parking and land use regulations related to the requirements for restricted charter boats, the license holder or agent of a restricted charter boat may only publish or broadcast the name of the boat, the name of the operator or captain of the boat, a telephone number where information may be obtained as to the scheduling of charter activity, and a description of the charter activity offered, but shall not list an address for the slip where the boat is docked or any landside facility from which it operates. 
(Code 1994, § 78-175; Ord. No. 95-7454, § 1, 6-7-1995; Ord. No. 00-8850, § 1, 6-7-2000; Ord. No. 01-9193, § 1, 5-16-2001) 
Sec. 42-207. - Enforcement. 
    The license of any charter boat or landside facility in violation of any of the provisions of this article may be subject to suspension by the city manager for up to 30 days, after notice and opportunity for hearing; or revocation by the city council. Violations under this article may also be enforced under the code enforcement provisions of article VII of chapter 2. Employees of the city authorized to enforce charter boat regulations include code enforcement officers, law enforcement officers, city dock staff and the city manager or designee. 
(Code 1994, § 78-176; Ord. No. 95-7454, § 1, 6-7-1995; Ord. No. 01-9193, § 1, 5-16-2001) 
Subpart B - LAND DEVELOPMENT CODE[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Local Government Comprehensive Planning and Land Development Regulation Act, F.S. § 163.3161 et seq. 

Chapter 44 - GENERAL PROVISIONS 

Sec. 44-1. - Title. 
    This code shall be known as and may be referred to as the "City of Naples Land Development Code," and may also be referred to as the "land development code." 
(Comp. Dev. Code 1990, § 1-1; Code 1994, § 82-1) 
Sec. 44-2. - Intent and purpose. 
(a)  This land development code contains standards intended to ensure that neighbors and adjacent and neighboring properties are protected from potential negative impacts in developing and using a parcel of land. This land development code also contains standards intended to preserve and protect the health, safety and general welfare of the community. In addition, it is the intent of the land development code to protect the character and property values of the city, to protect the assets of the city and their economic value as it relates to the city as a tourist-oriented community, and to maintain and enhance the attractive nature of the city. 
(b)  As required by F.S. § 163.3202, this land development code contains specific and detailed provisions necessary or desirable to implement the adopted city comprehensive plan and regulates the subdivision of land, the use of land and water, signage, stormwater management and environmentally sensitive lands. The land development code also provides for the protection of potable water wellfields and ensures that public facilities and services meet or exceed the standards established in the capital improvement element of the comprehensive plan. In addition, the concurrency management system requires that proposed development is conditioned on the availability of public facilities and services. 
(Comp. Dev. Code 1990, § 1-2; Code 1994, § 82-2) 
Sec. 44-3. - Relationship to existing regulations. 
    To the extent that the provisions of this land development code are the same in substance as the previously adopted provisions that they replace in the city's Code of Ordinances, including the zoning and subdivision ordinances, they shall be considered as continuations thereof and not as new enactments unless otherwise specifically provided. In particular, a situation that did not constitute a lawful nonconforming situation under the previously adopted zoning ordinance does not achieve lawful nonconforming status under this land development code merely by the repeal of the zoning ordinance. 
(Comp. Dev. Code 1990, § 1-3; Code 1994, § 82-3) 
Sec. 44-4. - Interpretation. 
(a)  In the interpretation and application of this land development code, all provisions shall be liberally construed in favor of the governing body, and deemed neither to limit nor repeal any other powers granted under state statutes. 
(b)  No use, structure, condition or development shall exist upon any property unless permitted in its district and location pursuant to this code or by applicable general law. 
(Comp. Dev. Code 1990, § 1-4; Code 1994, § 82-4; Ord. No. 08-12308, § 1, 12-17-2008) 
Sec. 44-5. - Effect on existing covenants and restrictions; conflicting regulations. 
    This land development code is not intended to repeal, abrogate or impair any existing easements, covenants or deed restrictions. However, where this land development code conflicts or overlaps with other regulations, whichever imposes the more stringent restrictions shall apply. 
(Comp. Dev. Code 1990, § 1-5; Code 1994, § 82-5) 
Sec. 44-6. - Severability. 
    It is hereby declared to be the intention of the city council that the sections, paragraphs, sentences, clauses and phrases of this land development code are severable, and, if any such section, paragraph, sentence, clause or phrase is declared unconstitutional or otherwise invalid by any court of competent jurisdiction in a valid judgment or decree, such unconstitutionality or invalidity shall not affect any of the remaining sections, paragraphs, sentences, clauses or phrases of this land development code, since such provisions would have been enacted without the incorporation into this land development code of such unconstitutional or invalid section, paragraph, sentence, clause or phrase. 
(Comp. Dev. Code 1990, § 1-6; Code 1994, § 82-6) 
Sec. 44-7. - Rules of construction generally. 
    For the purpose of this land development code, words used in the present tense shall include the future. The singular number shall include the plural, and the plural the singular. The word "structure" shall include the word "building." The word "shall" is mandatory, and the word "may" is discretionary. 
(Comp. Dev. Code 1990, § 2-1; Code 1994, § 82-8) 
Sec. 44-8. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this land development code, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Access aisle means an element of off-street vehicular use areas providing paved accessibility from the accessway to off-street parking or loading spaces or other vehicular use areas. 
    Accessory use or structure means a use or structure on the same lot with and of a nature customarily incidental and subordinate to the principal use or structure. 
    Accessway means an element of off-street vehicular use areas comprising the paved area providing the entrance to or exit from the street right-of-way at the property line, leading to the access aisle. 
    Accretion means slow addition of sand to the beach which increases beach size; the opposite of erosion. 
    Adjacent concurrency service areas mean concurrency service areas which are contiguous and touch along one side of their outside geographic boundary. 
    Airport clear zone. See High noise impact areas . 
    Alley means a recorded right-of-way which affords only secondary means of access to abutting property and which is not intended for general traffic circulation. 
    Ancillary facilities mean the building, site and site improvements necessary to provide support services to a school district's educational program including, but not limited to vehicle storage and maintenance, warehouses or administrative buildings. 
    Architectural embellishment means a design element surmounting a building's roof, including but not limited to minor cupolas, towers, and monitors, accessible only for maintenance purposes, intended as a decorative, nonfunctional feature. See section 56-39 (height requirements, exceptions thereto) Elements that function as part of a roof over habitable space, such as a rotunda, are not considered architectural embellishments. 
    Areas of public concern means areas which pose unique land use problems or conflicts, or have the potential for such problems in the future; in some cases they require development of significant environmental impact assessment or general development and site plan approval. 
    Arterial road means a road which provides relatively continuous service, high traffic volume, long trip length and high operating speed. 
    Available capacity means existing school capacity which is available within a concurrency service area including any new school capacity that will be in place or under actual construction, as identified in the first three years of the school district's five year capital improvement plan. 
    Bakery, retail, means a combination bakery and baked goods sales shop at which all of the baked goods produced are sold at retail on the premises. 
    Balcony means a platform enclosed by a parapet or railing that projects from the wall of a building and is not within the general outline or profile of the building. 
    Basement means a portion of a dwelling located partly underground but having less than half its clear floor-to-ceiling height below the average grade of the adjoining ground. 
    Beach means the zone of unconsolidated material that extends landward from the mean low-water line to the place where there is a marked change in materials or physiographic form, or to the line of permanent vegetation, usually the effective limit of storm waves. "Beach" is alternatively termed "shore." 
    Beach end means an improved area where the street meets the beach, used for parking and disembarking. 
    Boatyard and boatway mean a commercial marine facility which provides such facilities as are customary and necessary to provide complete construction, reconstruction, repair or maintenance, including lifting or launching services, for all types of marine craft and equipment, in addition to such wet or dry storage as may be necessary for the repair activities. 
    Building means any structure having a roof and used or built for the shelter or enclosure of persons, animals or property of any kind. 
    Building area, relative to single-family residential lots, means that portion of lot coverage which is the sum total of all lot area covered by roof and which is enclosed by walls or any other enclosure system. Mesh screening shall not be considered a wall or enclosure system. Building area is calculated as the area within the outermost perimeter of the enclosing walls or enclosure system. 
    Building height in commercial zoning districts, including HC, C1, C1-A, C2, C2-A, C3, C4, I, M, O, PD, and D, means the vertical distance measured from the FEMA 1st habitable floor height requirement to the peak of the roof or the highest point of any appurtenance attached to the roof. 
    Building height in multifamily residential districts, including R3-6, R3-12, R3T-12, R3-15, R3T-18, R3-18, R3-15CS, and R3-15MO, means the vertical distance measured from the greater of: 
(1)  The FEMA 1st habitable floor height requirement; 
(2)  18 inches above the state department of environmental protection requirement for the 1st habitable floor structural support; 
(3)  18 inches above the elevation of the average crown of the adjacent roads; or 
(4)  The average natural grade (the natural contours of a land area generally unaltered by human intervention); 
to the highest point of a flat roof, the deck line of a mansard roof, or the mean height between the eaves and ridge of a gable, hip or gambrel roof. 
    Building height in single-family residential districts, including RE, R1-E, R1-15A, R1-15, R1-10, R1-10A, and R1-7.5, means the vertical distance measured from the greater of: 
(1)  The FEMA 1st habitable floor height requirement; 
(2)  18 inches above the state department of environmental protection requirement for the 1st habitable floor structural support; 
(3)  18 inches above the elevation of the average crown of the adjacent roads; or 
(4)  The average natural grade (the natural contours of a land area generally unaltered by human intervention); 
to the highest point of the roof surface or parapet. 
    Capital improvement means physical assets constructed or purchased to provide, improve or replace a public facility and which are large-scale and high in cost. The cost of a capital improvement is generally nonrecurring and may require multiyear financing. 
    CBRA means the Coastal Barrier Resources Act of 1982 (16 USC 3501 et seq.). 
    CDBG means community development block grant. 
    Cellar means a portion of any dwelling having half or more than half of its clear floor-to-ceiling height below the average grade of the adjoining ground. 
    Certificate of public facility adequacy means a certificate issued concurrently with the final local development order which verifies public facility capacity is available to service a development. 
    Channelized means physically directing traffic flow by means of islands, barriers or curbing which forces vehicle traffic into specific lanes; this encourages free-flowing traffic. 
    Child care center means an enterprise involving the care of 3 or more children at one and the same time, either by day or night, which children are not foster children or related by blood or marriage to the operator. 
    City high-hazard areas means areas seaward of the most restrictive line of the following: state coastal construction control line, Federal Emergency Management Agency designated velocity zones (FEMA V zones) and erosion-prone bay frontage. 
    Clinic means an establishment where persons, who are not lodged overnight, are admitted for examination or treatment by 1 person or a group of persons participating in any form of the healing arts, including physical therapists or laboratory technicians under the supervision of a doctor, whether such persons be medical doctors, chiropractors, osteopaths, chiropodists, naturopaths, optometrists, podiatrists, dentists or any such profession, the practice of which is regulated by the state. 
    Cluster or cluster development means a development in which a number of dwelling units are grouped, leaving some land for common use. Residential projects of 3 or more units, or over 1/2 acre in size, may employ the concept of clustered development whereby residential units are grouped to provide a more efficient design of infrastructure and to provide useable open space for the residents. Clustered developments must comply with the density and lot coverage requirements for the parcel. However, minimum lot requirements may be decreased provided the land thus saved is allocated to useable open space areas for the residents of the project. The maintenance of the open space areas is the responsibility of the owner. 
    Cocktail lounge means a vendor who sells primarily beer, wine, or alcoholic beverages for consumption on the premises and derives less than 51 percent of gross revenues in food in any period of time between the hours of 7:00 a.m. and 2:00 a.m. the following day. 
    Coastal area of the city. For planning purposes, the entire city is considered to lie within the coastal zone boundary. This is due to the interrelationships of land and water areas. 
    Coastal barrier island means a geological feature which is completely surrounded by marine waters that front upon the open waters of the Gulf of Mexico, Atlantic Ocean, Florida Bay or Straits of Florida and are composed of quartz sands, clays, limestone, oolites, rock, coral, coquina, sediment or other material, including spoil disposal, which feature lies above the line of mean high water. Mainland areas which were separated from the mainland by artificial channelization for the purpose of assisting marine commerce shall not be considered coastal barrier islands. 
    Coastal high-hazard areas means areas designated by local governments, and includes areas which have historically experienced destruction or severe damage, or which may experience destruction or severe damage, from storm surge, waves, erosion or other outcomes of rapidly moving or storm-driven water. 
    Collector road means a road that provides service of moderate traffic volume, moderate trip length and operating speed, and collects and distributes traffic between local and arterial roads. 
    Commercial fishery means a commercial establishment for the receiving, processing, packaging, storage and wholesale or retail distribution and sale of products of the sea. Such an establishment may include facilities for the docking, loading, unloading, fueling, icing and provisioning of vessels and for the drying, maintenance and storage of equipment. 
    Commercial vehicle means any vehicle designed, intended or used for the transportation of people, goods or things, other than private passenger vehicles and private trailers used for the nonprofit transportation of goods and boats. 
    Commercial zoning district means the following zoning districts: C1 retail shopping district, C1-A commercial core district, C-2 general commercial district, C2-A waterfront commercial district, C3 heavy commercial district, C4 airport commercial district, M medical district, O office district, and D downtown district. 
    Comprehensive plan means a plan that meets the requirements of F.S. § 163.3177 and F.S. § 163.3178. 
    Cones of influence means contour lines associated with water wells which exhibit groundwater depth and the area in which groundwater movement occurs as water is extracted from the water wells. 
    Concurrency service area means a geographic area in which the level of service for a school of each type is measured when an application for residential development is reviewed for school concurrency purposes. 
    Conservation areas means locations of critical environmental concern such as mangrove areas, natural drainageways, beaches and freshwater wetlands. This designation also applies to those areas which are presently isolated from urban development and which lack essential public services and facilities. Conservation areas include marginal land, class III waters, and parks and open space; see the future land use and conservation/coastal elements of the comprehensive plan. 
    Cooking facilities means any appliance or manufactured unit (i.e., Pullman kitchen unit) used for the preparation of food. 
    Curbline radii means the curvature of street curbs at intersections. 
    DCA means the state department of community affairs. 
    Debt service projections means the city's financial obligations for previously funded capital improvement projects, or repayment of revenue bonds. 
    Density means the number of residential dwelling units permitted per acre (43,560 square feet) of land. Streets, alleys, swamplands, mangrove areas and areas covered or to be covered by water (except land to be covered by water for on-site stormwater retention purposes, or as a landscape architectural feature, and which is not part of a platted lake or drainage easement) are not included in the calculation of net acreage. In the determination of the number of residential dwelling units to be permitted on a specific parcel of land, a fractional unit larger than 0.50 shall entitle the owner to an additional unit. 
    Department store means a retail establishment occupying a minimum of 60,000 square feet of gross leasable area, offering a wide variety of merchandise and services, and organized into departments according to the kinds of goods sold. 
    Development means the carrying out of any building activity or mining operation, the making of any material change in the use or appearance of any structure or land, or the dividing of land into 3 or more parcels (F.S. § 163.3221(4)). 
    Development order means any order granting, denying or granting with conditions an application for a development permit (F.S. § 163.3164(7)). 
    Development permit includes any building permit, zoning permit, subdivision approval, rezoning, certification, special exception or variance, or any other official action of local government having the effect of permitting the development of land (F.S. § 163.3164(8)). 
    Dock means any structure, otherwise known as a pier, wharf or loading platform, which is constructed on pilings over open water, or which is supported by flotation on the water. 
    Dockage area means less than ten boat slips. 
    Dormer means a small gable projecting from a sloping roof holding a window set vertically. The size of a dormer is relative to the proportion of the roof it projects from and is not a dominant element of this roof slope. 
    DOT means the state department of transportation. 
    Drainage basin means topographic boundaries which contribute stormwater to a drainage system or estuarine or ocean waters. 
    Drawdown means the underground depth of water as it relates to a water well site. 
    Drive-in business means any place of business or premises which serves, sells or otherwise makes available its services or products to patrons situated in automobiles. 
    Driveway means the paved area leading from the edge of a street pavement to the accessway at the property line. 
    DSEI means development of significant environmental impact. 
    Dune means a mound or ridge of loose sediments, usually sand-sized, lying landward of the beach, and deposited by natural or artificial mechanism. 
    Dwelling district refers specifically to districts RE, R1-E, R1-15, R1-15A, R1-10, R1-10A, R1-7.5, R3-6, R3-12, R3T-12, R3-12CS, R3-12MO, R3-15, R3T-18, and R3-18, and PD zoned property designated for a residential use. 
    Dwelling unit means a single unit providing complete independent living facilities for one or more persons, including permanent provisions for living, sleeping, eating, cooking and sanitation. 
    Educational facility means the buildings and equipment, structures and special educational use areas that are built, installed or established to serve educational purposes only. 
    Effluent means something flowing out of a body of water, sewer or storage tank; for example, wastewater effluent. 
    Extermination means the control and elimination of insects, rodents or other pests by eliminating their harborage places, by removing or making inaccessible materials that may serve as their food, or by poisoning, spraying, fumigating, trapping or by any other recognized and legal pest elimination method approved by the enforcing official. 
    Fallout shelter means a structure or portion of a structure intended to provide protection to human life during periods of danger to human life from nuclear fallout, airraids, storms or other emergencies. 
    Family means an individual or 2 or more persons related by blood, marriage, law or legal adoption, or not more than 4 persons not so related living together as a single housekeeping unit in a dwelling unit. Foster children and domestic servants employed on the premises shall be considered as related by blood, marriage, law or legal adoption. 
    Feeder trunk line means a collection of pipes which feed main lines for the sewer and wastewater effluent reuse system. 
    FEMA means the U.S. Federal Emergency Management Agency. 
    Flood and flooding mean a general and temporary condition of partial or complete inundation of normally dry land areas from the overflow of inland or tidal waters or the unusual and rapid accumulation or runoff of surface waters from any source. 
    Floodplains means areas inundated during a 100-year flood event or identified by the National Flood Insurance Program as an A zone or V zone on flood insurance rate maps or flood hazard boundary maps. 
    Floor area and gross floor area shall be determined by measuring the outside wall dimensions of all enclosed floor area under roof, excluding basements, uninhabited attics, garages, carports and screen-enclosed areas. 
    Florida inventory of school houses - permanent capacity means the report of the permanent capacity of existing public school facilities. The Florida inventory of school houses capacity is the number of students that may be housed in a facility (school) at any given time based on a percentage of the total number of existing student stations and a designated size for each program. 
    Foster care facility means housing which provides a family living environment, including supervision and care necessary to meet the physical, emotional and social needs of the residents, and which serves either children or adult foster residents. 
    Four Corners means the intersection of U.S. 41 and 5th Avenue South. 
    Garage sale means a garage, yard, lawn, patio or similar type sale held anywhere on any residential premises for the purpose of disposing of personal property, typically found in a residential household or garage, by the resident of the premises where the sale is held. 
    Gasoline service station means a place of business at which the principal service is the retail sale of gasoline. 
    Gate house means an accessory nonresidential building or structure which is utilized by a security guard or gatekeeper for the exclusive purpose of controlling access to a parcel of property. 
    Grocery store means establishments dispensing food of any kind, other than bakeries, for consumption off the premises, and having a gross floor area of 1,500 square feet or more. 
    Gross leasable area means the total floor area designed for tenant occupancy and exclusive use, including mezzanines and upper floors, if any, expressed in square feet, measured from the centerlines of joint partitions and exteriors of outside walls. 
    Groundwater recharge means areas where water enters the ground and is stored in an aquifer and is later extracted for public use. 
    Guest unit means an accessory dwelling unit on the same property as a permitted primary residence or any assemblage of rooms functionally detached from the primary residence. Garages, utility sheds, open air shelters, pool baths, cabanas and similar structures not to be used for habitation shall not be considered guest units. 
    Hazardous waste means solid waste which may cause or significantly contribute to an increase in mortality or serious illness or which may pose a substantial present or potential hazard to human health or the environment. 
    High density residential means intended to accommodate multifamily residential densities of up to 18 dwelling units per net acre. 
    High noise impact areas means areas surrounding Naples Municipal Airport where potential noise impact exists from low-flying aircraft, designated as the 65 Ldn noise contour. 
    Historic resources means areas, districts or sites containing properties listed on the Florida Master Site File or National Register of Historic Places, or designated by a local government as historically, architecturally or archaeologically significant. 
    Home occupation means an occupation carried on as a secondary use in a residence by the occupant of a residential dwelling unit. The use of a telephone in a residence for business purposes is not considered a home occupation. 
    Horticultural landfill means the landfill located east of Goodlette-Frank Road and south of the public works complex that is the storage location for all citywide plant clippings. 
    Hurricane vulnerability zone means areas delineated by the regional or local hurricane evacuation plan as requiring evacuation. The hurricane vulnerability zone shall include areas requiring evacuation in the event of a 100-year storm or Category 3 storm event. 
    Infrastructure means public facilities serving the needs of the population, including roads, bridges, sewage disposal and potable water systems, solid waste disposal sites, piers and docks. 
    Inland waters includes all tidal waters and all streams, lakes, canals or bay bottom lands as are in fact navigable, but does not include beaches fronting on the Gulf of Mexico. 
    Interceptor means pumps that transmit sewage and wastewater to treatment plants or lift stations. 
    Kitchen means a portion of a building used or that could be used for the preparation of food, and shall include cooking facilities, and may include a sink, food refrigeration and preparation facilities, food and utensil storage and dining facilities. Any and all of such features and related improvements, i.e., wiring, plumbing and the like, shall be removed when a kitchen has been determined by the building official to have been installed in violation of this land development code. 
    Landscape material means any of the following or combination thereof: shrubs, vines, hedges, grasses, and plants. 
    Level of service is an indicator of the extent or degree of service provided by or proposed to be provided by a facility based on and related to the operational characteristics of the facility. Level of service shall indicate the capacity per unit of demand for each public facility. 
    Lift station interceptor. A lift station interceptor is similar to an interceptor with sewage being transported toward a treatment plant and effluent reuse being transmitted away from the treatment plant. 
    Littoral zone means the intertidal and near-shore subtidal area of the shoreline. 
    Live entertainment means a use in conjunction with a restaurant, cocktail lounge or other similar establishment, wherein floorshows or other forms of entertainment consisting of one or more persons, amplified or non-amplified, are provided indoors or outdoors. Live entertainment requires a live entertainment permit in accordance with section 56-125. 
    Lot. A lot is a lawful building site. Such building site may consist of all portions or combinations of land parcels described by metes and bounds or lots as shown on a subdivision plat. 
    Lot area means the total area, measured in a horizontal plane, within the lot lines of a lot. 
    Lot coverage means that percentage of a lot or parcel of land that is covered or occupied by all buildings, including accessory buildings, under the terms of this land development code. Fences, shuffleboard courts, swimming pools and the like shall not be included in computing lot coverage. Balconies and means of egress shall be included in determining building coverage if either of the following conditions exists and to the extent that such conditions exist: 
(1)  Balconies and means of egress project more than six feet from the building wall of any floor. 
(2)  The combined length of balconies and means of egress on any one floor level along a building wall exceeds 50 percent of the length of the wall. 
    Lot depth means the horizontal distance between the rear lot line, or the narrowest front lot line in the case of lots with two frontages, or the intersection of the side lot lines, and the midpoint of the front line, measured back from the midpoint in the mean direction of the side lot lines; also the line so described. 
    Lot line means the lines bounding a lot as defined in this section. 
    Lot of record means a lot which is part of a platted subdivision or a parcel of land recorded in a county deed book or official record book. 
    Lot width means the horizontal distance between the side lot lines, or between the side lot line and the longest front lot line, measured at right angles to the lot depth at a point midway between the front and rear or narrowest front lot line. 
    Low density residential means intended to accommodate single-family or other similar residential uses of up to approximately six dwelling units per net acre. 
    Marijuana has the meaning given cannabis in F.S. § 893.02(3). 
    Marijuana farm means any property used in whole or in part for the growing or cultivation of marijuana plant(s). 
    Marina means an establishment with a waterfront location designed to service watercraft. A marina may include such activities as refueling and lubrication of watercraft, covered or uncovered boat slips or dock space, dry storage of watercraft, charter and sightseeing boat dockage, boat and boat motor sales or rentals, outfitting, maintenance and repair, including haul-out facilities, boat launching, retail sale of boating or fishing supplies and accessories, restaurants or refreshment facilities, laundry facilities or other customary accessory facilities. No boat manufacturing or major reconstruction is permitted. 
    Mean sea level means the average height of the sea for all stages of the tide. It is used as a reference for establishing various elevations within the floodplain. For purposes of this land development code, the term is synonymous with North American Vertical Datum of 1988 (NAVD 88). 
    Medical marijuana dispensary means a facility that is operated by an organization or business holding all necessary licenses and permits from which marijuana products, or plant(s) are delivered, purchased, possessed, or dispensed for medical purposes. 
    Medical marijuana treatment center means an entity that acquires, cultivates, possesses, processes, (including development of related products such as food, tinctures, aerosols, oils, or ointments), transfers, transports, sells, distributes, dispenses, or administers marijuana, products containing marijuana, related supplies, to qualifying patients or their personal caregivers. 
    Medical use means the acquisition, possession, use, delivery, transfer, or administration of marijuana or related supplies by a qualifying patient or personal caregiver for use by a qualifying patient for the treatment of a debilitating medical condition. 
    Medium density residential means intended to accommodate single-family and multifamily residential densities of up to 12 dwelling units per net acre. 
    Mixed use area is a designation to guide the development and redevelopment of bay-front property to allow for water-related and water-dependent uses as well as innovative waterfront development. 
    Mobile home means a single-family dwelling designed for transportation after fabrication on streets and highways on its own wheels or a flatbed or other trailer, and arriving at the site where it is to be occupied as a dwelling complete and ready for occupancy, except for minor and incidental unpacking and assembly operations, location on jacks or permanent foundations, connection to utilities and the like. 
    Mobile home park means an area designed, constructed, equipped, operated or maintained for the purpose of providing spaces for two or more mobile homes, intended to be used as temporary or permanent living facilities. 
    Model home means a residential structure used for demonstration purposes, not occupied as a dwelling unit and open to the public for inspection. 
    Motor vehicle means any self-propelled vehicle, fuel or electric or otherwise powered, including motorcycles and mopeds, excluding vehicles moved solely by human power. 
    MPO means the Naples/Collier County metropolitan planning organization. 
    Multifamily means two or more families. 
    Multifamily zoning district means the following zoning districts: R3-6 multifamily district, R3-12 multifamily district, R3T-12 multifamily district, R3-15 multifamily district, R3-18 multifamily district, R3T-18 multifamily district, R3-15 multifamily district Coquina Sands (CS), and R3-15 multifamily district Moorings (MOR). 
    Natural grade means the natural contours of a land area generally unaltered by human intervention. 
    NAVD 88 means North American Vertical Datum of 1988, a geodetic datum established by the National Ocean Service and frequently referred to as the Mean Sea Level Datum. 
    Nonconformity means a lot, structure or use of land, or any combination thereof, which was lawful before this land development code was passed or amended, but which would be prohibited under the terms of this land development code. 
    Non-medical marijuana sales means the purchase, sale, transfer or delivery of marijuana, cannabis, cannabis-based products or cannabis plant(s) when such sale, transfer or delivery is not associated with any medical purpose or use, whether or not such purchase, sale, transfer or delivery is lawful under federal or state law. 
    Nonpoint source pollution means a combination of pollution sources that are dispersed in such a way that a specific single source of the pollution cannot be identified; for example, agricultural fertilizer runoff. 
    Nursery school means any structure, lot or premises where a commercial or institutional establishment is maintained or operated temporarily or permanently for the training or care, other than medical care, of preschool-age children. 
    Nursing, rest or group home means a home, institution, building or residence, public or private, whether operated for profit or not, which provides accommodations, maintenance, personal care or nursing for a period exceeding 24 hours to three or more ill, physically infirm, aged persons or others in need of physical or mental rehabilitation, who are not related by blood or marriage to the operator. 
    Office means a business facility in which business administration, business service and business transactions occur, but in which there is no on-premises display or sale of merchandise. 
    Open space means undeveloped land suitable for passive recreation or conservation uses. 
    Ornamental buffer. Ornamental buffers shall be a minimum of six feet high and shall be composed of structural or plant materials. Within one year of installation, and at all times thereafter, ornamental buffers shall be at least 75 percent opaque and shall be maintained in a neat, attractive condition. 
    Ornamental screening means framed construction or other material, including a parapet wall, which conceals rooftop heating, ventilating and air conditioning equipment, and which is integrated into the overall design, textures, materials, and colors of the building. See section 56-39 (height requirements, exceptions thereto).   

Ornamental Screening 
    Paratransit means transit service such as ridesharing, carpools or vanpools, and demand-response buses. 
    PD is a zoning designation for planned development. A planned development allows a mix of well-designed residential, commercial, recreational and other uses. The PD district encourages imaginative, high-quality land planning by approving development compatible with surrounding land and activities. 
    Person means any individual, or any entity, partnership, association, corporation, company or organization of any kind. The masculine gender shall include the feminine, and the singular shall include the plural, where indicated by the context. 
    Personal caregiver means a person who is at least 21 years old who has agreed to assist with a qualifying patient's medical use of marijuana and has a caregiver identification card issued by the Florida Department of Health. A personal caregiver may assist no more than five qualifying patients at one time. An employee of a hospice provider, nursing, or medical facility may serve as a personal caregiver to more than five qualifying patients as permitted by the Florida Department of Health. Personal caregivers are prohibited from consuming marijuana obtained for the personal, medical use by the qualifying patient. 
    Point source pollution means a confined point of origin, such as pipes, ditches, conduits or wells, from which pollutants are or may be discharged. 
    Potable water facilities means a system which collects, treats and distributes drinking water, and includes water wells, treatment plants, reservoirs and distribution mains. 
    Premises means a lot, plot or parcel of land, including the buildings and structures thereon. 
    Principal building or principal structure means a building or structure which houses the main use or activity occurring on a lot or parcel of ground. 
    Private club means a property owned or leased and operated by a group or an association of persons and maintained and operated solely for the members of such a group or association and their guests, and which is not available for unrestricted public access or use and which is not operated for profit. 
    Proportionate share mitigation (schools) means an applicant improvement or contribution identified in a binding and enforceable agreement between the applicant, the school district and the local government with jurisdiction over the approval of the plat, site plan or functional equivalent to provide compensation for the additional demand on public school facilities caused by the residential development of the property, as set forth in F.S. § 163.3180(13)(e). 
    Public notice means at least 15 days' public notice, published one time in a newspaper of general circulation in the city, which states the date, place, time and nature of the business with which the notice is concerned. 
    Public utility means any publicly owned or publicly regulated facility for rendering electricity, gas, communications, transportation, water supply, sewage disposal, drainage, garbage or refuse disposal or fire protection to the general public. 
    Qualifying patient means a person who has been diagnosed to have a debilitating medical condition, who has a physician certification and a valid qualifying patient identification card. If the Florida Department of Health does not begin issuing identification cards within nine months after the effective date of the Constitutional amendment, then a valid physician certification will serve as a patient identification card in order to allow a person to become a "qualifying patient" until the Florida Department of Health begins issuing identification cards. 
    Refuse means putrescible animal and vegetable wastes resulting from the handling, preparation, cooking and consumption of food. 
    Residence means a single-family dwelling, or dwelling unit in a multifamily complex, which contains sleeping, bathroom and kitchen facilities. 
    Restaurant means an establishment where meals or prepared foods, including beverages, are served to customers. Establishments dispensing foods of any kind solely for consumption off the premises and having a gross floor area of less than 1,500 square feet shall be considered as retail sales establishments and not restaurants. Restaurants are hereby classified and further defined into 3 categories: 
(1)  Restaurant, conventional, means restaurants consisting of customer seating at tables, booths or counter stools, indoors or outdoors, and providing no service to persons at walk-up windows or counters or in motor vehicles, but shall include cafeterias. 
(2)  Restaurant, carryout and drive-up, mean restaurants specializing in short-order foods and beverages, including the preparation of food to be taken out and consumed off the premises, which may be entirely a counter stool-type operation, or have any combination of counter stools and tables and booths. No service provided to persons in a motor vehicle except for establishments dispensing foods from drive-up or walk-up windows or counters for consumption either on or off the premises is permitted under this classification. 
(3)  Restaurant, drive-in, means any restaurant serving food or beverages to persons in motor vehicles to be consumed on the premises. 
    Revetment means a sloping structure which serves to separate real property and any improvements thereon from any natural or human-made body of water. 
    Right-of-way means land to which the state, county or city owns the fee simple title or has an easement for transportation or utility use. 
    Riprap slope protection means any shore protection device constructed of loose rock or rubble or other material in a sloping configuration. 
    Rubbish means combustible and noncombustible waste materials, except garbage. 
    R/UDAT means the Regional/Urban Design Assistance Team, American Institute of Architects. 
    Saltwater/freshwater interface means the common boundary where saltwater and fresh water meet. 
    Saltwater intrusion means locations where saltwater blends into or intrudes into fresh water. 
    School board means the governing body of the school district, a political subdivision of the State of Florida and a corporate body pursuant to F.S. § 1001.40. 
    School District of Collier County means the school district created and existing pursuant to Section 4, Article IX of the State of Florida Constitution. 
    School capacity availability determination letter means, based upon a school impact analysis, a letter prepared by the school district, identifying if school capacity is available to serve a residential project, if capacity exists for each school type, and whether the proposed development is conceptually approved or vested. 
    School impact analysis means a detailed report which evaluates a development plan for a proposed residential development and identifies the anticipated student impact from the development on the level of service standard within the concurrency service area for each school type. 
    Seasonal population means part-time inhabitants who utilize or may be expected to utilize public facilities or services, but are not residents. Seasonal population shall include tourists, migrant farm workers and other shortterm and longterm visitors. 
    Seasonal population formula. The seasonal population formula is as follows: Housing units × vacancy rate × percentage of occasional housing × persons per household ° current number of motel/hotel units × state average of persons per party. 
    Seawall means any solid upright structure which serves to separate real property and any improvements thereon from any natural or human-made body of water. 
    SFWMD means the South Florida Water Management District. 
    Shopping center means a group of commercial establishments planned and developed as a unit, having a minimum lot area of three acres, with common off-street parking provided on the property. 
    Shoreline means a straight or smoothly curved line which, on tidal waters, follows the general configuration of the mean high-water line (1.09 feet above mean sea level, or as determined by U.S. Coast and Geodetic Survey datum), and which, on nontidal waters, is determined by the annual average water level. Small boat slips and other minor indentations shall be construed as lying landward of the shoreline and are considered upland when measuring required yards or computing the lot area of waterfront property. 
    Storage garage means a building or portion thereof designed or used exclusively for term storage of motor-driven vehicles, and at which motor fuels or oils are not sold and motor-driven vehicles are not equipped, repaired, hired or sold. 
    Story means that portion of a building included between a floor and the floor or roof next above it, including a loft area, carport or garage. If any part of a building is 2-story, the entire building is considered 2-story. 
    Street means a public or private thoroughfare which affords the principal means of access to abutting property. 
    Structure means anything constructed or erected, the use of which requires a permanent location on the ground or attachment to something having a permanent location on the ground. 
    Substandard means a housing unit lacking some or all plumbing facilities, or being overcrowded. Complete plumbing facilities include hot and cold running water inside the unit, a flush toilet and a bathtub or shower for the exclusive use of the occupants within the unit. An overcrowded unit is one with more than 1.01 persons per room. 
    Substantial change means a substantial or significant change to a site plan which may be, but is not limited to, a change which increases floor area by more than ten percent of the approved floor area, alters a specific site condition or design feature of importance in the original review process, or significantly affects the project or surrounding neighborhood, as determined by the building official. 
    Swales means depressions, commonly used in landscaping plans to retain and slow the movement of water. 
    SWFRPC means the Southwest Florida Regional Planning Council. 
    Tiered level of service means a graduated level of service standard by school type, used over time to achieve an adequate and desirable level of service standard at the end of a specified period of time, as allowed by the state statute. 
    Timesharing lodging means a use of a dwelling unit under an arrangement or plan whereby the use of the unit has been segmented over time so that the owners, lessees or holders, regardless of the form of ownership or form in which the right to use is expressed, of such dwelling units have a periodically recurring exclusive right to the use of either that unit or another unit in the same development, according to a predetermined fixed schedule, and only if the schedule would permit in any one year a change or turnover of occupancy five or more times. In timeshare lodging facilities, each unit may contain living and sleeping accommodations, sanitary facilities and kitchen or cooking facilities. Timeshare lodging, interval ownership, interval occupancy and similar uses shall be construed to be the same. The city council finds that timeshare lodging is distinguished from transient lodging in that: 
(1)  Occupancy is usually for weekly periods of time or longer. 
(2)  The units are not primarily intended for rent to the public. 
(3)  The units are usually larger in size than traditional hotel or motel units, and may be subject to a greater intensity of human occupancy. 
(4)  The facility is normally subject to a higher occupancy rate. 
(5)  Each unit typically includes complete living, sleeping, cooking and sanitation facilities. 
(6)  The facility and neighboring properties are subject to unique impacts as a result of marketing activities. 
(7)  The management characteristics have the potential of being substantially different from those of transient lodging facilities. 
(8)  Ownership is diffused rather than concentrated. 
(9)  Occupancy is not intended for the overnight tourist or traveler. 
(10)  Recreation facilities are usually more extensive and used more intensely. 
The distinguishing features listed in this definition are not intended to be all-inclusive. 
    Trail means Tamiami Trail-U.S. 41. 
    Transient lodging facility means a hotel, motel, motor lodge, tourist court, or similar building or group of buildings in which sleeping accommodations and sanitary facilities are offered to the public and intended for rental to transients with daily, weekly or seasonal charge. A transient lodging facility includes a unit, group of units, dwelling, building, or group of buildings, within a single complex of buildings rented to guests more than three times in a calendar year for periods of less than 30 days or one calendar month, whichever is less; or which is advertised or held out to the public as a place regularly rented to guests for periods of less than 30 days or one calendar month, whichever is less. It does not include condominium common elements. A transient lodging facility is distinguished from multifamily dwellings (such as apartments) where rentals are for periods of a month or longer and occupancy is by residents rather than transients. 
    Type of school means schools providing the same level of education, i.e. elementary, middle, high school, or other combination of grade levels. 
    Upland conservation area means native vegetation area consisting of pine and scrub oak communities. 
    Upland vegetation includes disturbed wetland sites, primarily Australian pine and palmetto areas. 
    Vegetative communities means ecological communities based on certain soils, vegetation and animals, i.e., coastal strands, oak hammocks and cypress swamps. 
    Vital areas is a land use designation which includes marine grass beds, tidal swamps and marsh areas, fresh water swamps and marsh areas, gulf beaches and dunes, and class II waters. 
    Water accelator means a process to soften water with the use of chemicals. 
    Water-dependent means development directly carried out on, in or adjacent to a body of water; usage requires access to water. 
    Water recharge areas means land or water areas through which groundwater is replenished. 
    Water-related means developments or activities not directly dependent on water access, which may provide goods and services associated with water-dependent uses. All motels and hotels within the city are considered water-related due to their proximity to the beach or bay. 
    Water resource means any and all water on or beneath the surface of the ground, including natural or artificial watercourses, lakes, ponds or diffused surface water, and water percolating, standing or flowing beneath the surface of the ground. 
    Water well area means the location of city water wells used for potable water consumption activities. 
    Wellfield means an area consisting of several water well sites which is used for extracting water out of the ground. 
    Xeriscape means drought-resistant or drought-tolerant landscaping. 
    Yard. 
(1)  Generally. Front, rear and side yards are identified as follows: 
a.  A yard which abuts a street or the gulf is a front yard. 
b.  All navigable waterfront yards other than gulf-front are rear yards. 
c.  All yards which abut an alley and are parallel to the front yard are rear yards. In the event of a lot which has more than one alley abutting it, the city manager shall determine which yard shall be the rear and side yards. 
d.  Rear yards, other than as described in subsections (1)a through c of this definition, occur only in the interior of a block and are parallel or nearly parallel to the front yard. 
e.  Yards, other than those described in subsections (1)a through c of this definition, which are perpendicular or nearly perpendicular to a front yard are side yards. 
(2)  Corner and double-frontage lots. Corner lots and double-frontage lots which are not on an alley and are not on navigable waters have two front yards, two side yards and no rear yards. A lot encircled by streets has only front yards.
