The dimensions of the area to be dredged will be finalized after a site visit by the city manager. Disturbance of productive substrates, such as oyster bars, may require mitigation. If so, a mitigation plan will be arranged with the city manager. The maximum depth of maintenance dredging shall not exceed below five feet mean low water. Removal of intertidal or subtidal sediment, organisms or vegetation from the littoral zone immediately adjacent to a seawall or beneath a dock will not be permitted. The width of this zone will be determined after a site visit by the city manager. Dredging will not be permitted adjacent to a proposed or newly constructed dock, if the dock could have been designed to avoid the need for dredging. Such design measures include positioning the dock appropriately along the shoreline, as well as bridging near shore shoal areas. 
iv.  Recapturing of existing submerged land up to and no further than the platted property line in manmade waterbodies, including only that backfilling necessary to level the land. This allowance does not apply to the R1-15A district, which is exempt from this subsection. 
2.  The application for approval of dredge and fill activities under subsection (a)(4)b.1. of this section shall contain the following information: 
i.  Affidavit of ownership of the upland property abutting the proposed construction activities. 
ii.  A written statement describing the proposed construction activities or project. 
iii.  A survey of the property depicting the property line, the existing mean high water line, mean low water line and the official bulkhead line. 
iv.  A plan or sketch of the proposed construction activities or structure sufficient in detail and quality to show the location and approximate relation of the construction to the mean high-water line, the mean low-water line, the official bulkhead line, the adjacent properties and existing coastal construction in the area, as well as a designation of soundings and elevations in the area of the construction and a simple description of shoreline vegetation and intertidal habitat. 
v.  An applicant denied a permit under this subsection can apply for a permit under subsection (a)(3) and subsection (a)(4)a. of this section. 
3.  The following activities associated with the construction of a dock or seawall shall be exempt from permit requirements: dredging in bottom lands that exceed six feet in depth at the mean low-water line or are located further than 100 feet from the nearest mean low-water line. This exemption shall not apply if state or federal approval is required, in which event such application shall be processed in the manner provided in subsection (a)(4) of this section. 
4.  The previous subsections notwithstanding, any proposed dredge and fill project that requires a permit from the state department of environmental protection under F.A.C. 40E-4 must apply for a city permit, as set forth in subsection (a)(3) of this section. 
(5)  Expiration of permit. Permits issued under this section shall be good for one year from the date of issuance. Extensions of this period may be granted by the city manager for an additional period of six months for good cause shown where delay has not been the fault of the applicant or the applicant's agents. 
(6)  Exceptions from permit requirement. No permit for docks, mooring piles or seawalls is required under this section. However, the construction of such devices is an improvement requiring the purchase of a building permit from the city under the Florida Building Code. Upon payment of the appropriate permit fees and evidencing that all required state and federal permits have been obtained, the permit shall be issued so long as the following conditions are met: 
a.  The dock complies with all regulations provided in section 56-93 of this Code. 
b.  All seawalls are designed by a professional engineer whose name, address and official seal appears on the construction plans. However, the following construction is exempt from the requirements of design by a professional engineer: 
1.  Riprap slope protection devices, where no vertical seawall is constructed; and 
2.  Repair of existing seawalls consisting of grouting, patching or replacement of tiebacks, but not including replacement of any section parts. 
(b)  Permit fee. The fee and charge for obtaining a permit for construction or excavation under section 52-92 of this section shall be as set forth in Appendix A, Fees and Charges Schedule, to this Code, which shall be payable at the time of filing the application. 
(Comp. Dev. Code 1990, § 10-6-2; Code 1994, § 114-133; Ord. No. 06-11158, § 1, 3-15-2006; Ord. No. 13-13302, § 3, 6-12-2013 ) 
Sec. 52-94. - Marina siting criteria. 
(a)  In order to ensure that any marina development is environmentally sound, certain criteria have been proposed by the Southwest Florida Regional Planning Council, the county, and the state. The city criteria are adapted from their discussions. 
(b)  The following development activities shall be preferred in descending order of priority: 
(1)  Upgrade or expand existing marina facilities, providing they will meet all environmental criteria, standards and concerns. 
(2)  Develop new marinas on previously disturbed sites or on sites that historically have been used for marina-related activities. 
(3)  Develop new marinas in transitional conservation (TC) areas only if the total disturbance to the environment is minimized and all disturbance is mitigated, according to the mitigation standards and guidelines established in this land development code. The total disturbance shall include all dredge and fill activities associated with the project, including the state department of environmental protection/U.S. Army Corps of Engineers jurisdictional wetlands and isolated wetlands, and all land clearing and site alteration that disturbs native plant assemblages or communities. Maintenance dredging, as defined in section 52-93(a)(2), of existing navigational channels and waterways shall be excluded. 
(c)  All non-water-dependent marina facilities must be sited outside vital areas, in appropriately zoned areas. This includes fuel storage tanks, dry storage areas, restaurants, bait and tackle shops, ship chandlers, gazebos and all similar structures cited in the marina definition in section 44-8. 
(d)  All new marinas must provide adequate facilities, including parking, sewage pump-out facilities, potable water and appropriate shore power capable of servicing the potential mix of vessels and vessel users. Public uses shall be encouraged. 
(e)  A spill containment and cleanup contingency plan must be developed and implemented. Such a plan must address petroleum and other hazardous materials spills and discharges resulting from vessel sinking, vessel fires, fuel transfer and dispensing accidents, storage tank overfilling or leaks, and similar events, as well as inspection and enforcement provisions. 
(f)  Marinas proposed for areas zoned C or TC must demonstrate that such a development is clearly in the public interest. 
(g)  Preference will be given to marina development projects that are situated in or close to well-flushed deep channels or natural waterways. Development proposals for marinas that require extensive dredging to create and maintain entrance or flushing channels will be discouraged. 
(h)  Preference will be given to marina development projects that are sited close to the anticipated end use destination for their tenants. 
(i)  All proposals for marina development must address maintenance of water quality. Naples Bay and the Moorings Bay system are class II waters, the Gordon River, the human-made residential canals, and the various tributaries of Naples Bay are class III waters, and Dollar Bay and the inland waterway to the south are in the Rookery Bay Aquatic Preserve and National Estuarine Research Reserve, which will eventually become Outstanding Florida Waters. Water quality criteria for these classes are set forth in F.A.C. ch. 62-302, and quality of Outstanding Florida Waters is discussed in F.A.C. 62-4.242. All proposals for marina development or redevelopment must present data establishing ambient water quality conditions, and a detailed description of a monitoring program designed to ensure applicable standards are maintained. 
(j)  If applicable, the monitoring program will be coordinated with the state department of environmental protection. If water quality deteriorates within the marina basin or in immediately adjacent waters as a result of marina development (a statistically significant water or sediment quality impact is one in which the marina data differ from the background receiving body data at a significance level of P = 0.05 (H O rejected at P = 0.05) or greater), the owners or operators will be formally notified of the water quality violation and required to commence corrective action within 90 days. If corrective action is not undertaken, the operating license will be voided. In addition, the owners or operators shall be fined a reasonable amount, as decided by the city council, which shall be used by the city to undertake corrective action relating to the water quality of the site. 
(k)  Any proposed marina facility must address the city's level of service standards for Naples Bay. This analysis will include the impacts of the proposed slips to the bay and address alternate sites and sizes for the proposed marina. 
(l)  All proposals for marina development shall include a manatee protection plan, which addresses, but is not necessarily limited to, the following issues: 
(1)  Programs for education and public awareness. 
(2)  Programs for posting and maintaining manatee and vessel speed control signs. 
(3)  An analysis of the anticipated mix of vessel drafts in relation to the controlling depth of the Gordon Pass to Naples Bay navigation channel, obtained from the most recent U.S. Army Corps of Engineers channel depth survey. If deemed necessary, the marina shall provide information on vessel draft limitations to its patrons. 
(m)  The following ranking system, based on water depth and native marine habitat criteria, is hereby established to determine the number of powerboat wet slips per length of marina shoreline. The table is modified from the county marina site ranking system. A ranking of high is given to a site that has adequate water depth and access, and will not impact native marine habitats. A medium ranking is given when there is adequate water depth and access, but native marine habitat will be impacted, and when water depth is less than -4 feet MLW, but native marine habitat will not be impacted. A low ranking is given to an area that does not have adequate depth or access, and where native marine habitat will be impacted. The power boat wet slip density ranges from 1 to 18 slips per 100 feet of shoreline. 
_____

(Comp. Dev. Code 1990, § 10-6-3; Code 1994, § 114-134)

Sec. 52-95. - Cone of influence. 
    See chapter 58, article III, division 2 for provisions relating to the SO-1 cone of influence special overlay district. 
(Comp. Dev. Code 1990, § 10-6-4; Code 1994, § 114-135) 
Sec. 52-96. - Moorings Bay system access channel. 
(a)  The channel dredged around the periphery of the Moorings Bay system in 1991, 20 feet in width, is hereby designated the Moorings Bay access channel. The channel is located 20 feet offshore of the shoreline, where no piers or docks were present at the time of dredging, and 15 feet offshore from any piers or docks that were present at the time of channel dredging. The channel alignment is shown on a series of aerial photographs that can be viewed in the offices of the city clerk. 
(b)  The designated 20-foot-wide channel shall not be obstructed by construction of piers, docks, mooring piles or similar structures, nor shall it be obstructed by vessels at anchor or moored to any structure, unless such obstruction has been permitted by the city. 
(c)  Exceptions related to subsection (b) of this section may be granted by the Moorings Bay taxing district advisory committee, upon petition. The petition shall be submitted to the city manager, who will prepare an evaluation for presentation to the Moorings Bay taxing district advisory committee at its next regularly scheduled meeting. The Moorings Bay taxing district advisory committee shall evaluate the petition based upon the uniqueness of the property, determine whether a need is clearly established for encroaching into the designated channel, and determine that the remaining unobstructed channel will be of adequate width to allow passage of vessels using the channel. 
(1)  No consideration of encroachment into the Moorings Bay system access channel shall be given based upon a statement of need related to the size of the vessel to be moored to the proposed structure. 
(2)  The petition shall include the names and addresses of the adjacent neighbors and the address of all property owners' associations in whose jurisdiction the petitioner's property is located. The neighbors and property owners' associations will be notified, in writing, at the petitioner's expense, of the variance petition hearing a minimum of 15 days before the date of the advisory committee meeting. 
(d)  The decision of the Moorings Bay taxing district advisory committee shall be considered final unless a notice of appeal is filed in accordance with subsection (e) of this section. 
(e)  Notice of appeal to a decision of the Moorings Bay taxing district advisory committee shall be filed by any of the affected parties listed in subsection (c)(2) of this section, within 15 days of the date of the advisory committee meeting. The notice of appeal, the decision of the advisory committee, and a staff analysis and recommendation will be submitted to the city manager for presentation to city council within 15 days of receipt of the notice of appeal. The city manager will place the appeal on the agenda for the next regularly scheduled city council meeting. The appellant and the other affected parties will be notified, in writing, of the date of the city council meeting. 
(f)  The application and fee for processing a variance application under subsection (c) of this section shall be as set forth in appendix A to this Code. 
(Comp. Dev. Code 1990, § 10-6-6; Code 1994, § 114-137) 
Secs. 52-97-52-120. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - CULTURAL AND ARCHEOLOGICAL RESOURCES 

Sec. 52-121. - Purpose of article. 
    It is the purpose of this article to promote the prudent use of the cultural and archeological resources of the city. 
(Comp. Dev. Code 1990, § 10-7; Code 1994, § 114-161) 
Sec. 52-122. - Local register of historic places. 
    See the city comprehensive plan, adopted January 4, 1989, section II, subsection G(5), for provisions relating to the local register of historic places. 
(Comp. Dev. Code 1990, § 10-7-2; Code 1994, § 114-163) 
Secs. 52-123-52-150. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - DEVELOPMENT OF SIGNIFICANT ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACT[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
State Law reference- Environmental control, F.S. ch. 403. 

Sec. 52-151. - Applicability of article. 
    All developments and their associated activities proposed to take place in conservation areas shall be required to submit a development of significant environmental impact (DSEI) assessment for review and approval by the city. The development of significant environmental impact assessment shall be coordinated with the general development and site plan (GDSP) review process provided for in chapter 46, in addition to those other permitting processes stated elsewhere in this Code. No building permits shall be issued until the development of significant environmental impact assessment has been reviewed by staff and the city's planning advisory board and approved by the city council. 
(Comp. Dev. Code 1990, § 10-8-1; Code 1994, § 114-191) 
Sec. 52-152. - Purpose of assessment. 
    The purpose of the development of significant environmental impact assessment is to encourage flexibility in the use of land, and the activities necessary to develop such uses, without delineating specific uses and activities permitted. The development of significant environmental impact assessment will ensure that the proposed uses or activities are compatible with the natural resources of the site and of the surrounding area. 
(Comp. Dev. Code 1990, § 10-8-2; Code 1994, § 114-192) 
Sec. 52-153. - Waiver of assessment requirement. 
    The requirement for a development of significant environmental impact assessment may be waived by the city manager in those instances where the county, state or federal permitting procedures require a similar environmental impact assessment process, provided the assessment meets the requirements set forth in this article and is submitted for review and approval as stated in this article. 
(Comp. Dev. Code 1990, § 10-8-3; Code 1994, § 114-193) 
Sec. 52-154. - Contents of assessment report. 
    The development of significant environmental impact assessment will be a detailed report describing the proposed project and its purpose. The report must be based on current data, acquired contemporaneously with other project-associated planning, and field-verifiable as to its validity. Data acquisition and report preparation must be accomplished by qualified professional environmental scientists, and the author of each section of the development of significant environmental impact assessment must be identified. The report shall include all of the analyses listed in this section, as applicable, and integrate the analyses of the elements listed in section 52-155(b) in sufficient detail to enable an assessment of the probable environmental impacts, beneficial and detrimental, of the proposed project. 
(1)  An analysis of the probable impact of the proposed project on the wetland, marginal and upland environments, including impacts on ecological systems such as the marine, estuarine, aquatic and terrestrial faunal and floral communities or assemblages, and on cultural resources. The analysis must address direct and indirect and short-term and long-term environmental impacts. In addition, cumulative effects must be analyzed, including but not limited to such factors as biological productivity, habitat quality, and surface water and groundwater resources, including wellfield recharge and protection, and the capacity to attenuate nutrient and pollutant loading. 
(2)  An analysis of other factors, such as water or air pollution, hazardous substances, undesirable land use patterns, impacts on adopted levels of service, intensity and density of use, threats to public health or other adverse factors that would be contrary to the goals, objectives, policies and programs set forth in the comprehensive plan of the city. 
(3)  A description and analysis of alternatives to the proposed project which would avoid some or all of the anticipated adverse environmental impacts or increase the beneficial environmental aspects of the project, and a description and analysis of measures which would mitigate for the unavoidable adverse impacts of the proposed project. An economic cost-benefit analysis shall be required for the proposed project, alternatives and mitigation proposals. 
(4)  If, as, and when received, a discussion of any objections and alternative suggestions raised by other interested parties, including federal, state and local regulatory and planning agencies and the general public. 
(5)  An analysis of all irreversible commitments of natural resources which would occur if the proposed project is implemented. 
(6)  For projects affecting wetlands, analyses of their effects on the capacity of the wetland to: 
a.  Receive and store surface water, contribute sheet flow to adjacent surface waters, and recharge groundwater. 
b.  Contribute to the quantity and quality of the water supply and to protect against saltwater intrusion. 
c.  Protect adjacent uplands from tidal and hurricane surges. 
d.  Provide seasonal or permanent habitat, transient corridor and foraging area for native plants and animals, particularly any rare, threatened or endangered species, as listed by the state and the U.S. Department of the Interior. 
(Comp. Dev. Code 1990, § 10-8-4; Code 1994, § 114-194) 
Sec. 52-155. - Additional submittal requirements. 
(a)  Required information. The following information must be provided as part of the development of significant environmental impact assessment: 
(1)  The names, addresses and telephone numbers of applicant and site owner. If the owner and applicant are different, an affidavit authorizing the applicant as the owner's agent must be supplied. 
(2)  The legal description of the property. 
(3)  A description of the proposed project, including the number of residential and nonresidential units or facilities and the rationale for the matching of project and site. 
(4)  A general location map and an aerial photo, at a scale of 1 inch equals 100 feet, of the project site, with overlays showing the following: 
a.  Site boundaries. 
b.  Location of the line demarcating the landward extent of the surface waters of the state, as defined in F.S. § 403.031 (the state department of environmental protection jurisdiction line), if applicable. 
c.  The location of the proposed project within the site. 
d.  The location of the coastal construction control line, if applicable. 
e.  Topographic maps showing upland and submerged elevation contours, major vegetative communities or assemblages, existing and proposed land use, existing and proposed public works (streets, utilities, easements, etc.), existing and proposed drainage, location of any proposed dredge and fill activities, and any other information requested by the city manager. 
f.  Tabular presentations showing data delineating the areal extent of the vegetative communities, uplands, wetlands and submerged lands of the site, including the percentages of each that will be modified by the proposed project and data on the area of impervious surface of the proposed project and the area of natural groundwater recharge that will be covered. 
(b)  Elements to be addressed. The following elements must be addressed either by incorporation into the analyses and discussions described in section 52-154, or as separate sections: 
(1)  Soil, substrate and groundwater review element. A review of the surface and subsurface geology and its relationship to projected site uses, with information such as soil boring data or drilling logs, aquifers to be tapped for water supplies, and the protection of the water table and deeper aquifers from project-related impacts to be included. 
(2)  Surface water and stormwater review element. 
a.  This element shall include a review of the existing natural and human-made surface water features and an explanation of any proposed alterations, such as dredge and fill, impoundment or other activities, which would change these features. 
b.  This element shall include a detailed description of the stormwater management plan, including all detention or retention features, control structures, swales, etc., and an analysis of the impact of the proposed system on receiving waters, including groundwater, and on adjacent properties and the overall drainage basin. 
c.  This element must also address the minimization and control of erosion, siltation, and turbidity resulting from site clearing, the development process and the completed project. 
(3)  Ecological review element. This element must contain an inventory of plants and animals identified from the project site, including migratory or transient species that could be expected to occur there. In addition, the stability and health of the species assemblages (communities) should be evaluated and quantitatively compared with available data on the same assemblages occurring in undisturbed areas of the county. 
(4)  Cultural resources review element. The project site, if applicable, must be evaluated for the presence of historic and prehistoric archeological resources. The documentation and presentation of such resources shall be in compliance with the county historical preservation ordinance. 
(Comp. Dev. Code 1990, § 10-8-5; Code 1994, § 114-195) 
Secs. 52-156-52-180. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - FERTILIZER USE AND MAINTENANCE OF URBAN LANDSCAPES[6] 

Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 17-14036 , § 1, adopted Oct. 4, 2017, amended art. VII in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former art. VII, §§ 52-181-52-189 was entitled "Lawn and Landscape Maintenance and Content of Fertilizer," and derived from Ord. No. 08-11972, § 1, adopted Mar. 5, 2008. 

Sec. 52-181. - Purpose and intent. 
    This article regulates and promotes the proper use of fertilizers by any applicator, requires proper training of commercial and institutional fertilizer applicators, establishes training and licensing requirements, establishes a prohibited and restricted application period, specifies allowable fertilizer application rates and methods, fertilizer-free buffer zones, low maintenance zones, and exemptions. This article requires the use of best management practices that provide specific management guidelines to minimize the negative environmental effects fertilizers and lawn maintenance debris have in and on the city and its natural and constructed stormwater conveyances, rivers, creeks, canals, springs, lakes, estuaries, wetlands, bays, and nearshore waters of the Gulf of Mexico. Collectively, these waterbodies are an asset critical to the environmental, recreational, cultural and economic well-being of the city and the public health. Overuse or misuse of fertilizer containing nitrogen, phosphorus, or both, can cause overgrowth of algae and other vegetation, obstructing stormwater conveyances and disrupting the natural aquatic ecosystem. Regulation of nutrients, including phosphorus and nitrogen contained in fertilizer, entering city waterbodies will help improve and maintain water and habitat quality. 
(Ord. No. 17-14036 , § 1, 10-4-2017) 
Sec. 52-182. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms, and phrases when used in this article shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning. Unless specifically defined below, words or phrases used in this article shall be interpreted so as to give them the meaning they have in common usage and to give this article its most reasonable application: 
    Applicator means any person who applies, in any manner, fertilizer to turf or landscape plants within the city as defined in this article. 
    Commercial fertilizer applicator means any person who applies fertilizer on turf or landscape plants within the city in exchange for money, goods, services, or other valuable consideration. 
    Fertilize, fertilizing, or fertilization means the act of applying fertilizer to a lawn (turf), specialized turf, or landscape plant. 
    Fertilizer means any substance that contains one or more recognized plant nutrients and promotes plant growth, or controls soil acidity or alkalinity, or provides other soil enrichment, or provides other corrective measures to the soil. 
    Heavy rain likely - heavy rain means rainfall greater than or equal to 50 mm (two inches) in a 24-hour period; and likely means the precipitation probability as used by the National Weather Service is at least 60 percent. 
    Impervious surface means a constructed surface, such as a sidewalk, road, parking lot, or driveway, covered by impenetrable materials such as asphalt, concrete, brick, pavers, stone, or highly compacted soils. 
    Institutional fertilizer applicator means any person, other than a non-commercial or commercial applicator, who applies fertilizer for the purpose of maintaining turf or landscape plants. Institutional applicators shall include, but shall not be limited to, owners and managers of public lands, schools, parks, religious institutions, utilities, industrial or business sites, and any residential properties maintained in condominium or common ownership. 
    Landscape plant means any native or exotic tree, shrub, or groundcover, excluding turf. 
    Leaching means the process by which soluble constituents are dissolved and filtered through the soil by a percolating fluid. 
    Low maintenance zone means an area a minimum of ten feet wide adjacent to waterbodies that is planted and managed in order to minimize the need for watering, mowing, etc. 
    Non-commercial fertilizer applicator means any person other than a commercial fertilizer applicator or institutional applicator who applies fertilizer on turf or landscape plants in the city, such as an individual owner of a single-family residential unit. 
    Saturated soil means a soil in which the voids are filled with water. Saturation does not require flow. For the purposes of this article, soils shall be considered saturated if standing water is present or the pressure of a person standing on the soil causes the release of free water. 
    Slow release, controlled release, timed release, slowly available, or water insoluble nitrogen means nitrogen in a form that delays its availability for plant uptake and use after application, or that extends its availability to the plant longer than a "rapid-release nitrogen" product such as ammonium nitrate or urea, ammonium phosphate or potassium chloride. 
    Turf, sod, or lawn means a piece of grass-covered soil held together by the roots of the grass. 
    Waterbody or waterbodies means any visible, standing or open body of water. This shall include, but not be limited to: municipal or private storm sewer systems, including inlets, conveyances and structures, ditches, swales, canals, creeks, rivers, streams, tidal waters, lakes, ponds, ponded water, standing water, marshes, swamps or any other body of permanent or temporary standing or visible water whether or not the waterbody is natural or man-made or contained by impervious surfaces on the bottom or sides and all wetlands and other surface waters as defined by Chapter 62-348, Florida Administrative Code (F.A.C.) as may be amended from time to time. 
    Wetlands means those areas that are inundated or saturated by surface water or groundwater at a frequency and a duration sufficient to support, and under normal conditions do support, a prevalence of vegetation typically adapted for life in saturated soils [see Chapter 62-340, F.A.C., as may be amended from time to time]. 
(Ord. No. 17-14036 , § 1, 10-4-2017) 
Sec. 52-183. - Applicability. 
    This article shall be applicable to, and shall regulate any and all, applicators of fertilizer within the city unless such applicator is specifically exempted by the terms of this article from the regulatory provisions of this article. 
(Ord. No. 17-14036 , § 1, 10-4-2017) 
Sec. 52-184. - Timing of fertilizer application; content and application rate; impervious surfaces; buffer zones; and mode of application. 
(a)  Timing of fertilizer application. 
(1)  No applicator shall apply fertilizers containing nitrogen, phosphorus, or both, to saturated soils, or if heavy rains are forecast in the next 24 hours. 
(2)  No applicator shall apply fertilizers containing nitrogen or phosphorus to turf or landscape plants during a period of time when the National Weather Service has issued a flood watch or warning, or a tropical storm watch or warning, or a hurricane watch or warning for any portion of the city. 
(b)  Fertilizer-free zones. No fertilizer shall be applied within ten feet of any pond, stream, waterbody, lake, canal, retention area, drain or drainage ditch, wetland, or other waterbody, or within ten feet from the top of a seawall or lake bulkhead. Newly planted turf and landscape plants may be fertilized in this zone only for a 60-day period beginning 30 days after planting, if needed, to allow the plants to become well-established. Caution shall be used to prevent direct deposition of nutrients into the water. 
(c)  Low maintenance zones. A voluntary ten-foot, low maintenance, "no-mow" zone is strongly recommended, but not mandated, from any pond, stream, waterbody, lake, wetland or from the top of a seawall. A swale or berm system is recommended for installation at the landward edge of this low maintenance zone to capture and filter runoff. No mowed or cut vegetative material may be deposited or left remaining in this zone or deposited in the water. Care should be taken to prevent the over-spray of aquatic weed products in this zone. 
(d)  Fertilizer content and application rate. 
(1)  Fertilizers applied to turf within the city shall be applied in accordance with requirements and directions provided by Rule 5E-1.003, F.A.C., as may be amended from time to time. 
(2)  Fertilizer applied to turf or landscape plants within the city must contain no less than 50 percent slow release nitrogen per guaranteed analysis label; guaranteed analysis and label are defined in F.S. Ch. 576, as may be amended from time to time. 
(3)  Fertilizer applied to landscaping plants, excluding turf, shall not be applied at a rate greater than one pound of nitrogen per 1,000 square feet per application. No more than four pounds of nitrogen per 1,000 square feet shall be applied to any landscaped area, excluding turf, in any calendar year. 
(4)  Fertilizer containing nitrogen shall not be applied before seeding or sodding a site and shall not be applied for the first 30 days after seeding or sodding, except when hydro-seeding for temporary or permanent erosion control in an emergency, such as wildfire, or in accordance with the stormwater pollution prevention plan for that site. 
(5)  Fertilizers should be applied to turf or landscape plants at the lowest rate necessary without exceeding the maximum rate per application, as provided in this article, unless a soil or tissue deficiency has been verified by an approved test. Soil testing must be performed at a University of Florida/Institute of Food and Agricultural Services (UF/IFAS) Extension Soil Testing Laboratory, a state-certified or other laboratory pre-approved by the city manager. 
(6)  Phosphorus fertilizer shall not be applied at application rates that exceed 0.25 lbs. P 2 O 5 /1,000 ft. 2 per application and not to exceed 0.50 lbs. P 2 O 5 /1,000 ft. 2 per year. The use of no phosphorus fertilizer is strongly encouraged, as Florida soils typically contain sufficient phosphorus for a healthy native or man-made landscape. 
(7)  The use of water from a reclaimed wastewater system must be in accordance with this article and required best management practices; if fertilizer other than that contained in the reclaimed water is to be applied, the cumulative nutrient loading shall not exceed those established in this article. 
(e)  Application practices. 
(1)  Spreader deflector shields are required when fertilizing via rotary (broadcast) spreaders. Deflectors must be positioned such that fertilizer granules are deflected away from all impervious surfaces, fertilizer-free zones and waterbodies, including wetlands. 
(2)  Fertilizer shall not be applied, spilled, or otherwise deposited on any impervious surfaces. 
(3)  Any fertilizer applied, spilled, or deposited, either intentionally or accidentally, on any impervious surface shall be immediately and completely removed to the greatest extent practicable. 
(4)  Fertilizer released on an impervious surface must be immediately contained and either legally applied to turf or any other legal site, or returned to the original or other appropriate container. 
(5)  In no case shall fertilizer be washed, swept, or blown off impervious surfaces into stormwater drains, ditches, conveyances, or waterbodies. 
(f)  Management of grass clippings and vegetative matter. In no case shall grass clippings, vegetative matter, and/or vegetative debris be washed, swept, or blown off into stormwater drains, ditches, conveyances, waterbodies, wetlands, sidewalks or roadways. Any material that is accidentally so deposited shall be immediately removed to the maximum extent possible. Grass clippings should be blown back onto lawn areas or removed. 
(Ord. No. 17-14036 , § 1, 10-4-2017) 
Sec. 52-185. - Exemptions; golf course application. 
(a)  The timing of applications, fertilizer content, application rate provisions, and other provisions set forth above in section 52-184 shall not apply to: 
(1)  Bona fide farm operations as defined in the Florida Right to Farm Act, F.S. § 823.14; 
(2)  Other properties not subject to or covered under the Florida Right to Farm Act that have pastures used for grazing livestock; and 
(3)  Any lands used for bona fide scientific research, including, but not limited to, research on the effects of fertilizer use on urban stormwater, water quality, agronomics, or horticulture. 
(b)  Application of fertilizers to golf courses, parks and athletic fields within the city shall comply with Rule 5E-1.003, F.A.C., as may be amended from time to time. Application rates shall not exceed rates recommended in Solutions for Life (SL) 191: "Recommendations for N, P, K and Mg for Golf Course and Athletic Field Fertilization Based on Mehlich III Extractant", and shall comply with the recommendations in the Florida Department of Environmental Protection document, "Best Management Practices for the Enhancement of Environmental Quality on Florida Golf Courses, 2012," as may be updated from time to time. 
(Ord. No. 17-14036 , § 1, 10-4-2017) 
Sec. 52-186. - Urban landscape maintenance - training and licensing requirements. 
(a)  Training. 
(1)  All commercial and institutional fertilizer applicators within the city shall abide by and successfully complete the six-hour training program in the " Florida Friendly Best Management Practices for Protection of Water Resources by the Green Industries " offered by the Florida Department of Environmental Protection through the University of Florida Extension " Florida-Friendly Landscaping(tm) " program, or an approved equivalent. 
(2)  Private, non-commercial fertilizer applicators are encouraged to follow the requirements of this article as well as the recommendations of the University of Florida, Institute of Food and Agricultural Sciences (IFAS) Florida Yards and Neighborhoods program when applying fertilizers. 
(b)  Licensing of commercial applicators. 
(1)  All commercial fertilizer applicators within the city shall have and carry in their possession at all times when applying fertilizer, evidence of certification by the Florida Department of Agriculture and Consumer Services as a Commercial Fertilizer Applicator pursuant to Rule 5E-14.117(18), F.A.C. 
(2)  All businesses applying fertilizer to turf and/or landscape plants (including, but not limited to residential lawns, golf courses, commercial properties, and multi-family and condominium properties) must ensure that at least one employee has a "Florida-Friendly Best Management Practices for Protection of Water Resources by the Green Industries" training certificate prior to the business owner obtaining a city business tax receipt. Owners of such businesses shall provide proof of completion of the program to the city. 
(Ord. No. 17-14036 , § 1, 10-4-2017) 
Sec. 52-187. - Enforcement and penalties. 
    The violation of any provision of this article shall subject the violator to any enforcement procedure and to the penalties provided in section 1-15 of this Code. This article may be enforced against any person actually committing the infraction and any owner or person in control of the property upon which the violation occurs or condition exists. Each day of violation shall constitute a separate offense. 
    Funds generated by penalties imposed under this section shall be used by the city for the administration and enforcement of F.S. § 403.9337, as may be amended from time to time and the corresponding sections of the ordinance codified in this article, and to further water conservation and nonpoint pollution prevention activities. 
(Ord. No. 17-14036 , § 1, 10-4-2017) 
Secs. 52-188-52-210. - Reserved. 
Chapter 54 - SUBDIVISION STANDARDS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Platting, F.S. § 177.011 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 54-1. - Intent of chapter; interpretation of chapter. 
(a)  It is the intent of this chapter to provide for minimum standards governing subdivisions; that is, both major subdivisions, and minor subdivisions which are also called lot splits. Such standards are necessary for the protection of the health, safety and general welfare of the citizens of the city. It is further the intent in this chapter to include by reference those regulations and minimum standards required to provide that protection. 
(b)  It is also the intent of this chapter to facilitate the lawful subdivision of property through flexible platting requirements and expeditious approvals where the standards contained in this chapter are met. 
(Comp. Dev. Code 1990, § 6-1; Code 1994, § 98-1; Ord. No. 11-12912, § 1, 6-1-2011) 
Sec. 54-2. - Applicability of chapter. 
    Except where specifically provided otherwise, this chapter shall govern all subdivision of land within the city. 
(Code 1957, § 20-18; Code 1994, § 98-3; Ord. No. 11-12912, § 1, 6-1-2011) 
Sec. 54-3. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Alley means a roadway dedicated to public use which affords only a secondary means of access to abutting property and is not intended for general traffic circulation. 
    Arterial street means a street which is designed to carry large traffic volumes, and which has been designated as an arterial street on the master street plan. 
    Collector street means a street which is designed to carry intermediate volumes of traffic, which serves to distribute traffic to and from arterial streets, and which has been designated as a collector street on the master street plan. 
    Combining means the removal of lot lines from preexisting parcels to make a larger parcel. 
    Local residential street means a street whose primary purpose is to provide access to the properties which front on it. 
    Lot, flag or landlocked means a lot that does not directly and fully front a street or alley and where access is provided by a narrow drive, easement or extension of the lot or not provided at all. 
    Lot split, see subdivision, minor. 
    Lot, through, means any lot having frontage on two parallel or approximately parallel streets. 
    Plat means a map for a subdivision. 
(1)  Final plat means the final map of a subdivision which has been provided final approval. 
(2)  Preliminary plat means the map showing the proposed layout of a subdivision, prior to or concurrent with development plan. 
    Private street means a recorded street owned and maintained by the abutting property owners. 
    Recombining means the reinstatement of previously approved or lawfully existing parcels to a preexisting parcel. 
    Subdivision means a division of a parcel or parcels of land for the purpose or having the effect, whether immediate or future, of transfer of ownership of development, of enlarging a parcel, of reducing the size of an adjoining parcel, or of increasing density or development intensity. There are two types of subdivisions: major subdivisions; and minor subdivisions, also called lot splits. 
(1)  Subdivision, major means any subdivision not classified as a minor subdivision. It includes, for example, any division which involves the establishment of a new street, the extension, change of location or vacation of an existing street; the division of a parcel into more than three parcels; and the division of a parcel containing more than five acres regardless of the number of resulting parcels, unless it does not involve any change in street lines, easements, or increase in density or development intensity. The term "subdivision" includes a resubdivision, and, when appropriate to the context, shall relate to the process of subdividing or to the land subdivided. 
(2)  Subdivision, minor (lot split) means any subdivision of residentially zoned property in which the division results in no more than three parcels; or no more than five acres of land; to the extent that it does not otherwise meet the definition of a major subdivision. 
(Code 1957, §§ 20-18, 20-19; Code 1994, § 98-4; Ord. No. 03-10303, § 1, 12-17-2003; Ord. No. 04-10591, § 1, 9-29-2004; Ord. No. 08-12016, § 1, 4-2-2008; Ord. No. 11-12912, § 1, 6-1-2011) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 54-4. - General requirements. 
(a)  It shall be a violation of this Code for any person to create a subdivision of, or to subdivide, or to otherwise divide, any land in the city, except in conformance with the provisions of this chapter and any applicable provisions of the comprehensive plan and this Code. 
(b)  No land shall be divided or subdivided, nor shall any subdivision occur or be created, platted, recorded or left unrecorded, nor shall any building permit for any structure to be constructed upon any land so subdivided be issued, unless such subdivision meets all of the provisions of this section and this Code of Ordinances and all of the provisions of any applicable federal, state and local laws, including the comprehensive plan. However, any portion of land which has been divided or subdivided (the "subdivided plat") from another larger tract of land (the "entire original tract") and which meets all of the following criteria may be platted upon approval of the city: 
(1)  The subdivided plat complies with the provisions of this Code and any applicable provisions of the comprehensive plan and this Code; 
(2)  The subdivided plat, by itself or in combination with an adjacent parcel of land under common ownership or control, abuts a public street or a city council-approved vehicular access easement which provides the exclusive means of access to the subdivided plat; 
(3)  The subdivided plat, by itself or in combination with an adjacent parcel of land under common ownership or control, meets the criteria for approval under section 54-31 for a subdivision plat of the subdivided plat, whether or not the entire original tract is then seeking or has previously obtained approval under section 54-31 for a subdivision plat; 
(4)  The only portion of the entire original tract for which a permit is then being requested in conjunction with a petition for approval under section 54-31 for a subdivision plat is the subdivided plat; and 
(5)  The portion of the entire original tract for which approval under section 54-31 for a subdivision plat is not then being sought or has not previously been obtained abuts a public street or a city council-approved vehicular access easement; and 
(6)  New construction proposed for permitting of four or more units in multiple family districts or new development in non-residential districts shall meet minimum yard requirements to all platted lot lines and shall not straddle or cover platted lot lines or easements. 
(c)  It shall be ineffective for the purposes of this Code for any person to transfer, sell, or otherwise convey any land by reference to, exhibition of, or other use of a plat of a subdivision of such land without having submitted a final subdivision plat of such land for approval as required by this chapter and without having recorded the approved final subdivision plat as required in this chapter. 
(d)  No approval of the final subdivision plat, improvement plans or authorization to proceed with construction activities in compliance with the same shall require the city to issue a development order or building permit if: 
(1)  It can be shown that issuance of said development order or building permit will result in a reduction in the level of service for any public facility below the level of service established in the city comprehensive plan; or 
(2)  Issuance of said development order or building permit is inconsistent with the comprehensive plan. 
    Anything in this chapter to the contrary notwithstanding, all subdivision and development shall comply with city ordinances regarding adequate public facilities. 
(Code 1994, § 98-5; Ord. No. 98-8146, § 1, 1-7-1998; Ord. No. 11-12912, § 1, 6-1-2011) 
Sec. 54-5. - Minor subdivision of single-family residential lots. 
    In general, subdivision of property requires submission and approval of a plat as provided in this chapter. However, a minor subdivision (lot split), combination, or recombination of single family lots may be approved by the city manager for the following: 
(1)  The reinstating of lots in the same locations, of the same sizes, and with the same dimensions as platted lots previously approved by the city as part of a recorded subdivision plat. 
(2)  In the case of a subdivision plat where the individual lots shown on the subdivision plat do not meet the dimensional requirements of the underlying zoning or in the case of unplatted lands, a single-family residentially zoned parcel may be split to create a new lot, provided that it meets the dimensional and performance standards of the underlying single-family zoning district. 
(3)  In the case of a subdivision plat where the individual lots shown on the subdivision plat meet the dimensional requirements of the underlying zoning, single family residentially zoned parcels may be split to create a new lot provided that it results in the same or fewer number of lots than provided on the subdivision plat and that each lot meets the dimensional and performance standards of the underlying single-family zoning district. 
(4)  The subdivision solely for the creation, moving or removal of easements. 
(5)  The reconfiguration of parcels in the R1-15A Zoning District in conformance with Code Section 58-114 and in conformance with the requirements set forth in this chapter. 
(6)  The minor subdivision of property that does not meet the above standards shall require city council approval. 
(Code 1994, § 110-95; Ord. No. 04-10591, § 2, 9-29-2004; Ord. No. 06-11264, § 1(98-6), 6-14-2006; Ord. No. 08-12016, § 2, 4-2-2008; Ord. No. 11-12912, § 1, 6-1-2011) 
Sec. 54-6. - Flood damage prevention standards for subdivision proposals. 
    All subdivision proposals and other proposed development shall meet the following standards (including manufactured homes): 
(1)  All subdivision proposals shall be consistent with the need to minimize flood damage; 
(2)  All subdivision proposals shall locate and construct public utilities and facilities such as sewer, gas, electrical, and water systems to minimize or eliminate flood damage; 
(3)  All subdivision proposals shall provide adequate drainage to reduce exposure to flood hazards; 
(4)  The special flood hazard area shall be delineated and the base flood elevations shown on tentative and final subdivision plats. 
(Ord. No. 07-11638, § 3, 5-16-2007; Ord. No. 11-12912, § 1, 6-1-2011) 
Sec. 54-7. - Zero lot line subdivisions. 
    Properties within multifamily districts and planned development districts may be subdivided such that individual attached or detached dwelling units may maintain zero foot side yards internal to the development provided that the following criteria are met: 
(1)  A perimeter platted lot line shall be established. 
(2)  The development shall meet the minimum yard requirements for the district to the perimeter platted lot line. 
(3)  Parking and density requirements for the development shall be calculated based on the property within the perimeter platted lot line. 
(4)  Each individually platted lot within the perimeter platted lot line shall have direct access to a public or private platted street. Access through an alley or driveway easement shall not be sufficient to meet this requirement. 
(5)  The plat dedication language shall include joint and individual easements and responsibilities. 
(6)  A plat note shall provide identification of specific covenants or deed restrictions and provide recorded reference on the plat prior to recording the plat. 
(7)  The covenant and deed restriction shall provide for the following: 
a.  Joint and individual ownership responsibilities and liabilities. 
b.  Easements as necessary for maintenance, drainage, access and parking. 
c.  Joint permitting approvals. 
d.  Building footprint controls. 
e.  A specific conflict resolution process that does not require the involvement of the city. 
f.  Density controls. 
g.  City approval of amendments to or termination of the covenants or deed restrictions pertaining to this paragraph. 
( Ord. No. 13-13237, § 1, 2-6-2013 ) 
Secs. 54-8-54-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - PLATS 

Sec. 54-31. - Approval procedure. 
(a)  Minor subdivisions. 
(1)  Application and approval procedures and requirements for minor subdivisions requiring city manager or city council approval are as follows: 
a.  An application on a form provided by the city manager. 
b.  Submittal of a current boundary survey, a current site survey, proposed site plan to scale and applicable title and ownership information. 
b.  As may be applicable, submittal of a statement of unified property control. 
(2)  Standards: 
a.  Single-family lots may not be reconfigured to create through lots unless the property fronts Gulf Street (according to plat of the Plan of Naples) or the majority of properties in the same block are through lots. 
b.  The proposed lot or lots in any above application shall each be conforming to the most restrictive underlying zoning district. 
c.  The proposed lot or lots shall each be served by individual central potable water service and central sewer service. 
d.  The proposed lot or lots shall each have acceptable access in terms of capacity and in terms of compliance with section 56-49 and section 54-61. 
e.  Reconfiguration of lots under this section shall not create flag lots. 
f.  Proposed lot lines shall be straight lines parallel or similar in orientation to existing lot lines. 
(b)  Major subdivisions. 
(1)  Application and approval procedures and requirements for minor subdivisions requiring city manager or city council approval are as follows: 
a.  An application on a form provided by the city manager. 
b.  Submittal of a current boundary survey, a current site survey, a proposed major subdivision plat conforming to the requirements of F.S. Ch. 177, or where such conformance is not practical due to the nature of the proposed plat, conforming to requirements prescribed by the city manager; and applicable title and ownership information. It is the intent of this paragraph that the plat should comply with F.S. Ch. 177 unless demonstrably impractical; that it must be in recordable form; and must be capable of describing the property for title and underwriting purposes. 
c.  As may be applicable, submittal of a statement of unified property control. 
(c)  If a zoning change is required, the applicant shall submit a rezone petition simultaneously with the application for preliminary plat approval. The city manager shall review the preliminary plat, and, if the city manager determines the plat to be in order, notice of public hearing before the planning advisory board shall be advertised in a newspaper of general circulation in the city at least 15 days prior to the public hearing, setting forth the date, time and place of the public hearing. The city manager shall notify owners of property located within 500 feet of the property involved in the petition, informing them of the date, time, place and reason for the public hearing. Failure to notify all owners of property located within 500 feet by mail will not render any action taken on such petition void. 
(d)  At the public hearing, the planning advisory board shall hear the petitioner or the petitioner's designated representative and all other interested parties who may appear and request to be heard. Following the public hearing and after review of the preliminary plat, the recommendation of the departments of the city, and the rezone petition, if applicable, the planning advisory board shall submit its recommendation, together with the minutes of the hearing, to the city council as soon as practicable. If rezoning is involved, the recommendation will be made simultaneously on the preliminary plat and the rezoning after public hearing on the rezone petition. 
(e)  After considering the recommendation of the planning advisory board, the city council may, after an advertised public hearing, by a majority vote of the council members present, approve or disapprove the preliminary plat by resolution. Action on any rezone petition submitted simultaneously with the preliminary plat shall be taken by ordinance in accordance with section 46-32. 
(f)  After city council has approved the preliminary plan, the subdivider shall have the construction plans and specifications prepared and shall submit copies thereof to the city manager for review. See section 54-33 for required information to be submitted with the construction plans. If the construction plans fully comply with all construction requirements, the city manager shall approve them and the subdivider may thereafter proceed with subdivision development. Subdivisions which have received preliminary plan approval may proceed in accordance with development standards which were in effect at the time of preliminary plan approval, with the following exceptions: If construction plan approval has not been granted within one year of preliminary plan approval, or if the subdivision has not been completely developed within five years of preliminary plan approval, the plan approval shall expire, and the plans must be submitted for review and reapproval. Plans thus submitted for review and reapproval shall comply with all regulations in effect at the time the plans are resubmitted. 
(g)  Record plats will be approved by the city council either when all improvements are completed in accordance with the approved construction plans, or when security has been posted guaranteeing completion of improvements satisfactory in form to the city attorney and city council, and equal in amount to 110 percent of the cost of all uncompleted improvements. A registered engineer shall prepare the cost estimate, and the estimate must be approved by the city manager and city council. 
(h)  The subdivider shall have a record plat prepared, and submitted to the city manager, along with an application, and make application for record plat approval. 
(i)  When the city manager reports that the plat fully complies with all city requirements, the city council may grant final approval to the record plat. 
(Code 1957, § 20-26; Code 1994, § 98-31; Ord. No. 94-7132, § 1, 2-16-1994; Ord. No. 99-8615, § 7, 9-1-1999; Ord. No. 11-12912, § 2, 6-1-2011) 
Sec. 54-32. - Preliminary plan approval. 
(a)  In addition to the requirements in section 54-31 the following standards and requirements apply. 
(b)  Along with the application for preliminary plan approval, the subdivider shall furnish evidence in writing from appropriate state and county agencies that the preliminary plan complies with all state and county laws applicable thereto. Pending site specific information, submittal requirements may include master utility plans, environmental impact statement, traffic impact statement and related infrastructure reporting. 
(c)  It is recognized that some forms of property development are not conducive to formal platting methods as required by general law, for example, platting of units subject to a ground lease, or of air rights. Such types of plats may be approved if they otherwise meet the standards in this chapter and if shown to create units that are marketable under title standards. 
(d)  The city may waive preliminary or final plat requirements that are not necessary for the protection of the public welfare. 
(Code 1957, § 20-27; Code 1994, § 98-32; Ord. No. 11-12912, § 2, 6-1-2011) 
Sec. 54-33. - Construction plan approval. 
    Construction plans shall be furnished by the subdivider to the city manager and utility providers conforming to the site plan or subdivision plat. Final plats shall conform to the approved preliminary plat. The city manager may allow deviations to the extent that they do not substantially amend the development as approved by council. 
(Code 1957, § 20-28; Code 1994, § 98-33; Ord. No. 11-12912, § 2, 6-1-2011) 
Sec. 54-34. - Required certificates and approvals on final plat. 
    Required certificates and approvals on the first page of the final plat, subject to site specific requirements and provisions of F.S. Ch. 177, shall contain, except as otherwise allowed below, legal description, certificate of ownership and dedication, owner's acknowledgement, mortgagee's consent, mortgagee's acknowledgment, surveyor's certification, city approvals to include engineer for the city, surveyor for the city, and city attorney, certificate of approval of city council, and certificate of approval of clerk of circuit court. The general form for the certificates and approvals shall be as prescribed by the city manager. 
(Code 1957, § 20-30; Code 1994, § 98-35; Ord. No. 11-12912, § 2, 6-1-2011) 
_____
Sec. 54-35. - Plat illustrations. 
    Illustrations for subdivision plats are as follows: 
(1)  Sketch plan. 

(2)  Preliminary plat. 

(3)  Record plat. 

(Code 1957, § 20-31; Code 1994, § 98-36; Ord. No. 11-12912, § 2, 6-1-2011) 
_____
Sec. 54-36. - Fees; recording of final plat. 
(a)  Lot split and subdivision plat fees are as set forth in appendix A to this Code. 
(b)  The subdivider shall have the final plat or plan recorded in the circuit court clerk's office and shall furnish to the city clerk one Mylar (reproducible) and three paper (nonreproducible) prints of the recorded plat or plan. 
(Code 1957, § 20-32; Comp. Dev. Code 1990, § 11-2; Code 1994, § 98-37; Ord. No. 11-12912, § 2, 6-1-2011) 
Secs. 54-37-54-60. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - DESIGN STANDARDS AND IMPROVEMENT REQUIREMENTS 

Sec. 54-61. - Streets. 
(a)  Conformance with master plan. The street system shall conform and be properly related to the master street plan, which is a part of the comprehensive plan of the city. 
(b)  Street extensions. The street system shall recognize and extend suitable existing streets and shall make possible the future extension of streets into adjacent undeveloped land where appropriate. 
(c)  Intersections with arterial streets. Subdivisions bounded by an arterial street shall be planned with widely spaced collector streets as main subdivision entryways from the arterial street. Local residential streets shall avoid intersecting arterial streets if possible. 
(d)  Driveway intersections. Local residential streets shall be planned so that residential lots will not have drives onto arterial streets. 
(e)  Angle of intersections. Intersections shall be as nearly at right angles as possible. 
(f)  Type of intersections. In residential areas, "T" intersections are preferable to 4-way intersections. 
(g)  Half streets and reserve strips. Half streets and narrow reserve strips on subdivision boundaries shall not be allowed except when the reserve strip is dedicated as public land or is an approved controlled access strip. 
(h)  Offset intersections. Street jogs with centerline offsets of less than 125 feet are prohibited. 
(i)  Radius of curves. A tangent of at least 100 feet in length shall be provided between reverse curves on collector streets. The minimum radius of centerline curvature on collector streets shall be 400 feet. 
(j)  Radius of curvature at intersections. Radius of curvature at back of curbline of street intersections shall be a minimum of 20 feet. 
(k)  Private streets. Private streets are prohibited unless specifically approved as part of a land development innovation. (See section 54-74.) 
(l)  Width of right-of-way. 
(1)  The minimum width of street right-of-way shall be as follows: 
a.  Arterial streets: 100 feet. 
b.  Collector I streets: 100 feet. 
c.  Collector II streets: 80 feet. 
d.  Local residential streets: 60 feet. 
e.  Turnaround diameter on dead-end streets (culs-de-sac): 100 feet. 
(2)  Subdivisions that adjoin existing streets which do not meet the minimum right-of-way requirements shall provide the following additional right-of-way: 
a.  The entire right-of-way shall be provided where any part of the subdivision is on both sides of the existing street. 
b.  When the subdivision is located on only 1 side of an existing street, 1/2 of the required right-of-way shall be provided. 
(3)  Engineering requirements may result in greater right-of-way requirements than the minimums stated in this subsection. For standard street cross sections, refer to the city development specifications. 
(m)  Curbs. Cement concrete curb, curb and gutter or valley gutter, as approved by the city, shall be constructed along both sides of all streets, except in the case of temporary street construction, in which case the city council may waive the requirement. For curb construction details, refer to the city development specifications. 
(n)  Pavement width. Minimum street pavement width, measured from face to face of standing curb, or pavement edge to pavement edge of valley gutter, shall be as follows: 
(1)  Arterial streets. Rights-of-way for arterial streets which fall within new subdivisions shall be dedicated by the developer of that subdivision. Arterial streets are always state primary or secondary streets, and construction participation by the developer is not required. A developer who wishes to build a temporary street in the right-of-way of a planned arterial street shall meet such requirements as the city council determines to be proper in that special case. 
(2)  Collector I streets. Two 20-foot pavements with a 12-foot landscaped median strip are required for collector I streets. The 12-foot strip includes curbs at the edges of the median. 
(3)  Collector II streets. Minimum width of collector II streets is 26 feet. 
(4)  Local residential streets. Minimum width of local residential streets is 20 feet. 
(5)  Dead-end streets. The paved turnaround diameter of dead-end streets (culs-de-sac) shall be 80 feet minimum. A landscaped cut-out in the center of the turnaround is required. Pavement width around the turnaround shall be consistent with the pavement width leading up to the turnaround. 
(o)  Construction specifications. All streets in new subdivisions shall consist of a properly prepared subgrade, an approved road base, and an asphaltic concrete wearing surface. For street construction details, refer to the city development specifications. 
(Code 1957, § 20-38; Code 1994, § 98-61) 
Sec. 54-62. - Alleys. 
    Alleys shall be provided at the rear of commercial and industrial properties, except waterfront properties. Where utilized, alleys shall be designed and constructed to accommodate their use by service vehicles. Alley right-of-way width shall be a minimum of 20 feet. 
(Code 1957, § 20-39; Code 1994, § 98-62) 
Sec. 54-63. - Blocks. 
(a)  Block lengths shall not normally exceed 1,500 feet. Exceptions may be made when blocks border arterial streets or the waterfront, or in other unusual design situations. 
(b)  Corner lots shall be at least 15 percent wider at the front building lines than the minimum width permitted in the zoning district in which they are located. 
(c)  Through lots and flag lots shall be avoided except where essential to provide separation of residential development from major streets or to overcome specific development disadvantages. 
(d)  Side lot lines shall be substantially at right angles to or radial to street lines where practicable. 
(Code 1957, § 20-40; Code 1994, § 98-63; Ord. No. 08-12016, § 3, 4-2-2008) 
Sec. 54-64. - Drainage. 
    An adequate storm drainage system, including necessary curbs, pipes, culverts, drop inlets, bridges, swale ditches, ponds, lakes and their outlets, subsurface drains, etc., shall be provided for the proper drainage of surface water. For construction details, refer to the city development specifications. 
(Code 1957, § 20-41; Code 1994, § 98-64) 
Sec. 54-65. - Canals. 
    Canal bottoms shall be a minimum of 5 feet below mean low water. (Throughout the city, mean low water is considered to be 1.09 feet below mean sea level.) Canal depth at the seawall or base of riprap shall be a minimum of 1 foot below mean low water. Canal bottom side slopes shall be 3 horizontal to 1 vertical. Seawall tops or top of riprap shall be a minimum of 5.5 feet above mean low water. The city council shall approve any riprap or seawall. For seawall, riprap and canal construction details, refer to the city development specifications. 
(Code 1957, § 20-42; Code 1994, § 98-65) 
Sec. 54-66. - Sidewalks. 
    Sidewalk locations shall be established by the city and indicated on the approved plat. Sidewalks may either be installed by the developer or left for later installation by lot owners. The city may install sidewalks through property assessment sidewalk construction programs, or, if determined by the city council to be for the protection of the health, safety and general welfare of the public, the city may install or repair sidewalks and the cost of such construction may be paid from the revenues of the city. 
(Code 1957, § 20-43; Code 1994, § 98-66) 
Sec. 54-67. - Utilities. 
(a)  Water service. The city water system supplies water to all portions of the city. No private potable water supplies will be permitted. Water distribution lines, sized and placed in accordance with the city development specifications, shall be installed and dedicated by the subdivider. If water service to other areas will be facilitated by installing larger mains than necessary to serve the developer's subdivision, the city may require that the larger pipes be installed. In this event, the city shall pay the difference between the actual cost and the cost which would have been incurred had larger pipes not been required. 
(b)  Sewer service. Most, but not all, of the city is served by the city sewerage system. When city sewers are too remote for practical hookup, waste disposal facilities acceptable to the county health department may be installed. Regardless of whether the subdivision will be initially connected to the city sewer system, a subdivision sewage collection system, sized and placed in accordance with the standards of the city development specifications, connected to every building lot, and suitable for future connection to the city sewer system, shall be installed and dedicated by the developer. The developer may connect the subdivision sewage collection system to a temporary sewage disposal plant until such time as the system is connected to the city sewerage system, at which time city maintenance of the subdivision collection system shall begin. 
(c)  Electric, telephone and television cable service. Electric, telephone and television cable service shall be provided to each building lot in accordance with the city development specifications. All wiring, including primary and secondary power lines, street lighting circuits, telephone lines and television cables, shall be underground in zones R1-E through R3T-18, C1 and C1-A. An exception to the underground wiring requirement may be made by the city council in the case of temporary service installation, or when the city council determines that underground installation is not economically or technically feasible. 
(Code 1957, § 20-44; Code 1994, § 98-67) 
Sec. 54-68. - Recreation areas and facilities. 
    Each subdivision shall be served by recreation lands and facilities appropriate to the needs of the subdivision's future residents. Appropriate recreation areas and facilities will vary with the size and nature of the subdivision. Subdivision developers may either dedicate recreation lands to the city for public recreation areas, or create recreation areas and facilities for the exclusive use of future residents of the subdivision. Gulffront subdivisions shall also contain public beach access, parking facilities and beach area sufficient in size to accommodate future subdivision residents. No specific recreation area or facilities requirement is made, but the planning board and city council shall ensure that an appropriate amount of recreation land and facilities are included in each new subdivision. 
(Code 1957, § 20-45; Code 1994, § 98-68) 
Sec. 54-69. - Planting of street trees in right-of-way; grassing of unpaved portions of right-of-way. 
    Street trees shall be installed along both sides of all subdivision streets. All unpaved portions of rights-of-way shall be seeded or sprigged. 
(Code 1957, § 20-46; Code 1994, § 98-69) 
Sec. 54-70. - Street numbers and names. 
(a)  Street numbers. Street numbers shall be assigned by the city manager. Numbering shall be coordinated with the postal service, emergency services, property appraiser, and other affected agencies. 
(b)  Street names. 
(1)  The city council may approve the name of a platted right-of-way and dedicated public easements through the platting process or when approving the subdivision of property abutting both sides of the right-of-way. A petition to name or rename an existing right-of-way may also be initiated by the following: 
a.  By direction of the city council; 
b.  By request of the county, emergency services, United States Postal Service, or property appraiser's office; 
c.  By submittal of a petition signed by the owners of 51 percent of the property fronting the right-of-way as measured along the linear feet of the private property fronting the right-of-way. 
(2)  Upon receipt of a petition or direction of the city council to name or rename a platted right-of-way, the city manager shall process the request, obtain clearance from the county, emergency services, the United States Postal Service, and the property appraiser's office and provide notice to all owners of property abutting the right-of-way 30 days prior to consideration of the request by the city council. The city council may approve a new name provided it has been cleared by all relevant agencies and meets the criteria outlined in subsection (b)(3) of this section. After approval by the city council, all appropriate agencies shall be notified of the change, and all maps, plats, and addressing shall be amended to be consistent with the change and/or deemed amended for all official purposes. 
(3)  Proposed streets which are obviously in alignment with others existing and named shall bear the assigned name of the existing streets. In no case shall the name for a proposed street duplicate or be phonetically similar to existing street names, and the fact that the name is sought to be distinguished only by employing a different designation of the type of public way, such as street, avenue, boulevard, drive, place, court and the like, shall not suffice. 
(Code 1957, § 20-47; Code 1994, § 98-70; Ord. No. 06-11105, § 1, 2-8-2006; Ord. No. 14-13416, § 4, 2-19-2014 ) 
Sec. 54-71. - Street name signs. 
    City-approved street name signs shall be placed at each street intersection by the developer or, upon request, by the city, with the cost payable by the developer. 
(Code 1957, § 20-48; Code 1994, § 98-71) 
Sec. 54-72. - Vehicular access to beaches. 
    In gulffront subdivisions, access to the beach shall be provided at intervals of approximately 1/2 mile, for the purpose of giving beach access to beach cleaning and maintenance equipment. 
(Code 1957, § 20-49; Code 1994, § 98-72) 
Sec. 54-73. - Permanent reference monuments. 
    Permanent reference monuments shall be placed within the subdivision and on the exterior boundaries thereof so as to provide definite reference points from which may be located any points, lines or lots shown on the plat. 
(Code 1957, § 20-50; Code 1994, § 98-73) 
Sec. 54-74. - Land development innovations. 
(a)  The standards of this chapter are matched to typical city subdivision development. If a unique land development project is proposed, incorporating design features which do not fully comply with all requirements of this chapter, the project may be approved under the following conditions: 
(1)  An application for approval of a unique land development plan shall be submitted and processed in the manner set forth in this chapter. If the proposed land development will require a change of zoning, the rezone application shall be submitted along with and processed simultaneously with the subdivision plan. 
(2)  Physical development quality of the proposed development must be equal to or better than that required by this chapter. 
(3)  Adjacent properties must not be adversely affected. 
(4)  The spirit and intent of this chapter must be met, and the proposed development must be an asset to the city. 
(b)  If the city council determines to approve the unique land development, it may do so even though the development plans fail to meet all the requirements of this chapter. In such event, the city council may make such alternate or additional requirements as it finds to be necessary in the particular case. 
(c)  Upon approval of a unique land development by the city council, the development plans shall meet all requirements of this chapter except as modified by the terms of the city council's approval. All approved variations from this chapter shall be clearly shown either on the approved development plans or shall be spelled out by the city council in its approval action. 
(Code 1957, § 20-51; Code 1994, § 98-74) 
Sec. 54-75. - Security guaranteeing completion of improvements. 
(a)  Where the required improvements have not been completed prior to the submission of the record plat, the approval of the plat shall be subject to the subdivider guaranteeing the installation of the improvements by filing a performance bond, cashier's check or other security acceptable to the city attorney and city council, in the amount of 110 percent of the construction cost, as approved by the city manager. Whenever security guaranteeing performance is posted, the security instrument may provide that portions of the security deposit, proportionate to the work completed, may be released to the subdivider as work progresses. The amount to be released shall be determined by the city manager in accordance with the provisions of this subsection, subject to the approval of the city council. The cost of any state and federal documentary stamps and any other fees for recording security instruments shall be paid in cash to the city by the subdivider. 
(b)  Amounts given as security in cash or by certified or cashier's check may, at the option of the subdivider and with the approval of the city, be deposited in an interest-bearing account, or invested in some other manner. Any interest which may be earned on such security furnished by a subdivider shall be due and payable to the subdivider upon satisfaction of the requirements and conditions of the bond. 
(Code 1957, § 20-52; Code 1994, § 98-75) 
Sec. 54-76. - Maintenance of improvements.
